According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." Other words on the technological endangered list are iPod, mp3 and Blackberry. In their place are iPhone, chat app WhatsApp and messaging site ooVoo. #keepup One of the most common plotlines in the short story competition was achieving sudden internet fame after posting a YouTube video. The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant, is also close to Kagoshima, a city of 600,000. Sakurajima's last deadly eruption was in 1914, when 58 people died. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume," said the study's lead author Dr James Hickey, who has now joined the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines. "From our data we think it would take around 130 years for the volcano to store the same amount of magma for another eruption of a similar size- meaning we are around 25 years away." A report on the activity of the volcano was published on Tuesday and teams from Bristol University and the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre took part. Their research showed that 14 million cubic metres of magma is accumulating each year, enough to fill London's Wembley Stadium 3.5 times over. They added that the rate at which the magma is accumulating is faster than it can be expelled in its regular smaller eruptions, which led them to infer that a major eruption is likely in the next 30 years. They made these assessments based on new ways of studying and modelling the volcano's magma reservoir. Scientists say they hope these findings can help authorities plan for major eruptions. Palmer anticipates being fined by the British Horseracing Authority (BHA) for breaching rules on Champions Day. "It was an oversight," Palmer told BBC Sport. Following a report from the Equine Welfare and Integrity Officer, Palmer and employees of fellow trainers Francois Rohaut and Jean-Claude Rouget were interviewed by stewards. Regina Hungerford, 56, denied hitting a 17-year-old student who was listening to music in her Merthyr Tydfil College class. However, a disciplinary panel determined that it was likely she had made contact with the student, labeling her behavior as "unacceptable." The Education Workforce Council suspended her, stating on Thursday that "the public interest is in favor of her being able to teach again." Mrs. Hungerford acknowledged shouting and slamming a book on the desk of the "provocative and disruptive" teenager listening to rap music, but she consistently denied striking his head. She was acquitted of a criminal charge of assaulting the student during a math lesson for those with learning difficulties. Yet, in November, a disciplinary panel concluded that, on the balance of probabilities, she likely made physical contact with the student's head or hand. The panel declared her actions as "inappropriate" and deemed them professional misconduct. During the hearing, the mother of three pleaded to preserve her "very rewarding" career, expressing how the allegations had "ruined her life" and describing the situation as a "miscarriage of justice," but she expressed a desire to continue teaching. On Thursday, Mrs. Hungerford learned she would be suspended from the teaching register for four months, with the opportunity to return after completing a behavior management course. Panel chairman Gareth Roberts stated this was the suitable sanction to "allow her to return to teaching within a short period of time," reiterating: "The public interest is in favor of her being able to teach again."

Inspectors visited the force following criticism of its response to government spending cuts last year. Police and Crime Commissioner Olly Martins claimed the report was "out of date." The inspectors acknowledged that the force was "moving in the right direction and the pace of change is increasing." HMIC stated that they had conducted another assessment in March and planned to return in May and July.

Their first stop during a busy schedule of public engagements was a visit to the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. This Unesco World Heritage Site is comprised of around 40,000 large black basalt columns emerging from the sea. It was the Royal couple's inaugural visit to Northern Ireland's most famous tourist spot. The causeway was formed when molten rock was pushed up through the earth's fissures, creating a lava plateau. Following this visit, the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh traveled to the nearby village of Bushmills to honor local soldier Robert Quigg, who received a Victoria Cross for his bravery at the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg earned this prestigious military award after risking his life in the line of fire to search for his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke unveiled a statue of the soldier and a commemorative stone, with a brief address given by his grandnephew, Leonard Quigg. The Royal couple then attended a reception at Portrush Golf Club, hosted by the mayor of the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. They later experienced a nostalgic journey on a steam train from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to the village of Bellarena, accompanied by local schoolchildren. Large crowds gathered in Coleraine as they boarded the five-carriage train, built in 1932. In Bellarena, the Queen officially opened the village's new train station. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh first traveled this historic Coleraine to Londonderry railway line in 1953, the year of her coronation, with the original station having opened in 1853. Earlier this year, Bellarena saw the opening of two new railway platforms as part of a £46m upgrade to the Coleraine to Londonderry railway line. Upon her arrival, the Queen unveiled a plaque commemorating the new development, greeted by well-wishers waving union flags and cheering. On Monday, the Royal visitor met Northern Ireland's first and deputy first ministers at Hillsborough Castle in County Down. This trip marks the third significant royal visit to Northern Ireland in recent weeks, following visits by the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall, and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh last visited Northern Ireland in June 2014.

The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) highlighted that London's most disadvantaged children outperformed those in northern England. According to the government, additional funding is being allocated to early years providers to assist children from low-income families and narrow the achievement gap. The survey also revealed that five northern city-regions collectively have nearly as many well-qualified residents (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million), yet IPPR predicts a growing demand for skilled workers in the North. IPPR has suggested 11 benchmarks for Chancellor George Osborne's key policy aimed at enhancing regional economies, including bridging the significant gap in development for children under five. IPPR's director Ed Cox stated, "Our economy will never thrive if our children and young people start life at such a disadvantage. He emphasized that for the Northern Powerhouse to succeed, economic powers must be extended across the North, enabling businesses and policymakers to foster an economy that promotes productive, resilient, and sustainable growth, with well-paying jobs, shared prosperity, and opportunities for all. The Department for Education affirmed its dedication to ensuring every child, regardless of their background, can reach their potential, noting that reforms have resulted in 250,000 more students attending good or outstanding schools in the North since 2010.

The launch of its anticipated flagship model has become a disaster for the leading smartphone manufacturer. As the South Korean company rushes to manage the situation, let's review the events so far: On August 2, Samsung introduced the Galaxy Note 7 with much excitement in New York, featuring innovations like an iris scanner. Initial reactions were positive, with high expectations as it was considered a major competitor to the upcoming iPhone 7. Sales began on August 19 in ten markets, including South Korea and the U.S., with European markets planned for October. By August 24, the first incidents of a Note 7 "exploding" surfaced in the media, followed by more reports of devices overheating, exploding, or catching fire. On September 2, Samsung announced a global recall of about 2.5 million Note 7 phones due to defective batteries, offering refunds or replacements. By September 8, the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration and airlines worldwide advised passengers against using the Note 7 on planes. The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission also recommended discontinuing the phone's use, issuing a formal recall on September 15. Samsung planned to resume sales in South Korea on September 28. By September 19, reports emerged of phones catching fire in China, though Samsung claimed Chinese devices used different batteries unaffected by the recall. Sales in South Korea resumed on October 1, while replacements were underway in the U.S. However, on October 6, a replacement Note 7 showed similar issues—a device emitted smoke on a Southwest Airlines flight, prompting evacuation. More reports followed of replacement phones overheating and igniting. By October 9, U.S. carriers AT&T and T-Mobile ceased offering new replacements and stopped selling the phone. Finally, on October 11, Samsung halted all sales to investigate the issues, advising users to power down and stop using their devices.

The London Fire Brigade (LFB) has proposed three plans to achieve savings, assuring no station closures or forced job losses for firefighters. Despite the 13 engines being out of service, attendance time targets have still been met, though reintroducing them could enhance response times by about four seconds for the first engine at a scene. An alternative plan by London Assembly Member Andrew Dismore suggests reinstating the 13 engines, saving costs through alternative staffing at stations with certain specialist appliances. Discussions on the proposals are set for 2 December, with public consultation on savings strategies to follow, according to LFB. The FBU stands against any removal of fire engines in London, stressing that post-Paris attacks, it's dangerous to reduce engine numbers, urging LFB to reconsider. "Last year's ten station closures increased response times; removing these engines might cause further delays," a spokesman noted.

The news agency's Twitter account was suspended, advising users to disregard all tweets until further notice. A false message claimed: "Breaking: Two Explosions in the White House and Barack Obama is injured." This tweet alarmed US markets, causing the Dow Jones Industrial Average to plummet by 150 points as it spread. On Tuesday evening, the FBI announced it was probing the incident. Shortly after the tweet emerged, White House spokesman Jay Carney reassured reporters that President Obama was unharmed, leading financial markets to swiftly recover. AP later confirmed: "The @AP twitter account has been hacked. The tweet about an attack at the White House is false." The account was restored by Wednesday. The agency revealed that the breach followed numerous attempts by hackers to obtain AP journalists' passwords and was working to resolve the issue. Spokesman Paul Colford stated that other Twitter accounts were disabled as a precaution and they were collaborating with Twitter to probe the breach. AP reporter Mike Baker tweeted: "The @AP hack occurred less than an hour after we received a cleverly disguised phishing email." The email appeared to be sent from another AP staffer, urging recipients to click a link to a "very important" Washington Post article. The link led to a fake login page asking for a staff ID and password, reports indicate. A group claiming allegiance to Syrian President Bashar al-Assad took responsibility, tweeting: "Ops! @AP get owned by Syrian Electronic Army! #SEA #Syria #ByeByeObama." The Syrian Electronic Army also claimed responsibility for similar breaches on the Twitter feeds of Agence France Presse, Sky News Arabia, al-Jazeera mobile, and CBS News. Two CBS accounts were suspended after posting fake messages on @60Minutes criticizing US support for "terrorist" rebels in Syria. On Tuesday evening, Twitter announced its investigation into the incident and urged users to be "extra vigilant" about phishing emails.

John McCormack continued driving his articulated lorry for an additional 30 miles after colliding with a vehicle on the A9, as reported in Perth Sheriff Court. The court heard that there were three children in the car at the time of the crash. The 46-year-old was sentenced to complete 250 hours of community service and received a two-year driving ban. Prosecutor Rebecca Kynaston explained that drivers heading north near the House of Bruar shopping complex saw McCormack driving towards them on the wrong side of the road. She described how the drivers managed to veer onto the verge to avoid a collision. Although the lorry missed these vehicles, a couple with three children in their car was not as fortunate. Ms. Kynaston stated that the lorry struck the offside of the car and scraped along it, explaining, "One might have hoped that would bring this to an end. The impact was significant enough to bend the truck onto its wheel." Police were able to stop the lorry further along the A9 after it had covered several miles in this dangerous manner. McCormack, from Kilmarnock, admitted to driving recklessly on the wrong side of the road on 11 April last year. He also admitted to failing to stop after an accident and operating a vehicle in a hazardous condition. Defense solicitor David Holmes shared that McCormack had decided to cease driving following the incident, as he could not recall the accident or how it occurred, only remembering a sneeze. Sheriff Lindsay Foulis remarked that while McCormack had no memory of the event, he recalled sneezing before the crash. Foulis noted, "Five vehicles had to take evasive action. It doesn't take much imagination to understand the potential consequences of crossing into the opposite lane on a major road."

In a statement, it was announced that Foreign Affairs Secretary Perfecto Yasay would address the issue at a significant two-day Asia-Europe summit beginning on Friday, with China's Premier Li Keqiang present. On Tuesday, a UN-backed tribunal declared that China's claims in the South China Sea lacked legal foundation, a ruling China has vowed to disregard. China argues that the panel lacks jurisdiction and asserts that its activities in the region will remain unchanged. The Asia-Europe Meeting Summit (Asem) in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, on Friday and Saturday will be the first prominent multilateral diplomatic event since the 12 July ruling on the South China Sea. Leaders from 53 Asian and European nations, including Vietnam and Malaysia, which also have claims in the area, will attend. This will also mark the new Philippine government under President Rodrigo Duterte's debut on the international stage. The Department of Foreign Affairs stated that Mr. Yasay, representing Mr. Duterte, would "discuss within Asem's agenda the Philippines' peaceful and rules-based approach to the South China Sea and the necessity for all parties to respect the recent decision." This represents the Philippines' strongest stance on the ruling so far. Mr. Duterte has shown a more conciliatory approach compared to his predecessor, Benigno Aquino, expressing willingness to share resources with China in contested areas if the tribunal ruled in favor of the Philippines. The ruling was initially welcomed as a "milestone decision" by the Philippines, albeit without much fanfare. China, claiming nearly the entire South China Sea, has stated the summit is "not a suitable place to discuss" the matter. Assistant Foreign Minister Kong Xuanyou told Reuters, "It should not be put on the agenda." The arbitration tribunal’s ruling on Tuesday, initiated by the Philippines under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), which both countries have signed, stated that China had violated the Philippines' sovereign rights and inflicted "severe harm to the coral reef environment" by constructing artificial islands. Although binding, the Permanent Court of Arbitration lacks enforcement power.

"This event has been an impressive display of all that's positive, strong, and admirable about Wales," said Mr. Crabb. He noted that the collaboration with the Welsh government and First Minister Carwyn Jones was "remarkably effective." Their goal was to ensure that everyday politics didn't overshadow Wales' unity. Over 60 world leaders, 4,000 delegates, and 1,500 journalists gathered at the Celtic Manor Resort for one of the UK's largest international events. Mr. Crabb stated: "We aimed to showcase Wales' hospitality, infrastructure, and facilities to the world, and I believe we've achieved that this week. We emphasized the need for the Nato summit to have lasting economic benefits for Wales, and I think our heightened global profile will contribute to that. With the investment summit planned following the Nato event, we're focused on attracting more inward investment. Hosting world leaders, prime ministers, and ambassadors has been part of this strategy." The UK Investment Summit, scheduled for 20 and 21 November, will also occur at the Celtic Manor. US President Barack Obama commended the warm Welsh reception, highlighting the nation's "extraordinary beauty, wonderful people, and great hospitality." Despite hopes for long-term gains, Cardiff traders reported that security measures negatively impacted their businesses, deterring customers. First Minister Carwyn Jones expressed gratitude to residents and businesses for their support and "patience during some unavoidable disruption." "This has been an exceptional week for Wales," he remarked. "President Obama himself gave us high praise, noting our country's beauty, people, and hospitality, and encouraging Americans to visit. Our next step is to maintain this momentum." Cardiff council assured that security barriers would be removed by Sunday afternoon. As part of summit promotions, world leaders received willow baskets filled with Welsh gifts. Previously, Google Assistant was exclusively available on Google's own Pixel smartphones. Similar to Siri on iPhones, this service allows users to interact with apps and ask questions. LG was among the first to announce that its new device, the G6, would feature this assistant. Starting this week, Google will begin rolling out updates for users with Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat, enabling them to use Google Assistant. "This update allows hundreds of millions of Android users to experience Google Assistant," stated Gummi Hafsteinsson, the product lead for Google Assistant, in a blog post. However, there are other virtual assistants in the market. At the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Lenovo Moto announced that Amazon's Alexa would be integrated into the Moto Z phone. This integration will occur through an alternative back, known as a MotoMod, that Amazon plans to offer for the Moto Z later this year. Additionally, at the CES tech show in Las Vegas last month, Huawei, a Chinese tech giant, announced it would also incorporate Amazon's Alexa into its phones. Unlike its competitors, Google Assistant is designed to engage users in conversations and address follow-up questions. "Expanding Google Assistant to as many smartphones as possible is logical for Google because AI is central to its strategy," explained tech analyst Ian Fogg from IHS Technology. "The machine learning behind Google Assistant AI means that the more people use it, the smarter it becomes." Initially, Assistant will be available to English-speaking users in the U.S., followed by those in Australia, Canada, and the UK. Google plans to add support for more languages later on.

The election commission, Inec, aims to declare the winner by Monday. Despite technical issues, protests, and Boko Haram-related violence, the UN has commended the election. Voting extended to a second day in some Nigerian areas due to issues with new electronic card readers. President Jonathan was among those affected, unable to vote with the new technology meant to curb fraud. His party, the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), criticized the card readers, labeling the situation a "huge national embarrassment." Inec chair Attahiru Jega noted that only a few of the 150,000 card readers used nationwide malfunctioned. Voting was postponed by six weeks due to the Boko Haram insurgency. The poll's unpredictability remains as Nigeria decides in 2015: Full coverage. Islamist militants attacked polling stations in northeastern states, leading to a curfew in Bauchi State after clashes between security forces and the group. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon lauded Nigerian voters' "determination and resilience," despite Boko Haram's and others' attacks, stating that voting was "largely peaceful and orderly." The regional bloc Ecowas echoed his sentiments, urging Nigerians to accept the results. However, tensions simmer in the southern Rivers State, where thousands protested alleged opposition worker killings and voting irregularities. Inec expressed "concern" over these complaints, noting that one of its offices was set ablaze during the unrest. Election results are expected throughout Sunday night, but there are no official indications yet of a leading party. The PDP has been a dominant force since 1999, but Gen Buhari's All Progressives Congress poses a significant challenge. Voters are also selecting members of the house of representatives and the senate.

Geoffrey Stewart, 74, from Dumfries, was among three men in their 60s and 70s who disappeared in the Southern Uplands on Tuesday. Authorities reported that he passed away late Wednesday night at Dumfries and Galloway Royal Infirmary. Earlier that day, George Crosbie, 73, also from Dumfries, had died. Bobby Thomson, 64, the third man, is still hospitalized. Mr. Stewart's family released a statement expressing love and thoughts for all affected families during this tragic time, and extended gratitude to the rescue and hospital staff. The men, who didn't return from a hike in the Durisdeer hills on Tuesday, prompted a search by 16 members of the Moffat Mountain Rescue team and two search dogs, which continued into early Wednesday. The search was paused due to heavy rain, snow, high winds, and poor visibility but resumed at 08:30 with over 50 participants, including neighboring rescue teams and a Coastguard helicopter. The men were located that afternoon and airlifted to the hospital. Police stated that Mr. Crosbie died soon after, while his companions were treated for hypothermia. Colin Golphin, leader of Moffat MRT, noted the rapidly worsening weather overnight and extended condolences to the victims' families. The men were experienced hikers and regular visitors to the Lowther Hills, well-acquainted with the terrain.

Between January and March, the number of unemployed people decreased to 1.69 million, a reduction of 2,000 from the previous quarter, while the unemployment rate stayed at 5.1%, according to the ONS. Employment rose to 31.58 million, an increase of 44,000 from the last quarter, pushing the employment rate to a record 74.2%. However, job vacancies fell by 18,000 to 745,000, marking the first decrease in almost a year, as noted by the ONS. David Freeman, a senior statistician at the ONS, remarked that while the employment rate reached a new high, the rise was modest, suggesting a potential cooling in the jobs market. Average earnings, including bonuses, grew 2% from the previous year, slightly up from 1.9% in the previous quarter. The ONS indicated that bonus timing influenced this earnings increase. Excluding bonuses, earnings grew by 2.1% annually in the three months to March, down from 2.2% in the previous period. The claimant count for jobless benefits dropped by 2,400 in April to 737,800, though revised data showed a 14,700 increase between February and March, the largest since autumn 2011. Stephen Crabb, Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, highlighted the record-breaking employment figures and the decade-low unemployment rate at 5.1%. Economists expressed concerns, with David Kern of the British Chambers of Commerce noting that while employment hit a record, broader economic indicators suggest a slowdown. Paul Hollingsworth from Capital Economics agreed, indicating the slowdown has impacted job recovery. Meanwhile, Martin Beck from the EY Item Club cautioned that with unemployment at pre-crisis levels, continued rapid declines like those in 2015 are unlikely.

Taibu, aged 32, participated in 28 Test matches and 150 one-day internationals for Zimbabwe before retiring in 2012. "When he introduced himself, I initially thought it was a prank," said Nick Gordon, the publicity officer for Hightown. "As our conversation progressed, we checked references from contacts in Zimbabwe's cricket scene, and we've been in touch since. It's a significant achievement for us." The wicketkeeper-batsman could make his debut for the Second Division team against Alder on April 24. Speaking to BBC Radio Merseyside, Gordon mentioned that Taibu reached out to the club after seeing their ad for an overseas player for the summer. "It's not every day a club like Hightown St Mary's acquires a player of Tatenda's caliber," Gordon remarked. "I was taken aback; it was quite unexpected. We advertised for young players, but he said, 'I'm not young, I'm a retired Test cricketer.' "This man has played at an elite level, and we're willing to take the chance. Even if he hasn't played since 2012, he's more than capable of meeting our requirements this summer." The signing of this former international, who scored 1546 runs in Test cricket, surprised not only Hightown's players but also their competitors. "Initially, there was complete disbelief," Gordon noted. "The players thought it was a joke, but gradually, excitement built up about his arrival. We rarely get such opportunities at the club level. "There's definitely some envy—I've noticed comments on Twitter questioning how we managed it. But people are eager to face him. "These are regular guys with nine-to-five jobs who'll be playing against an international Test captain on Saturdays. "It's fantastic for local cricket too."

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, meaning "fuel shortage in a film," surged to become France's leading Twitter trend on Tuesday with over 5,000 tweets. A strike against new labor laws has impacted all eight of France's oil refineries, causing about 20% of fuel stations to either run out of petrol or have limited supplies. French social media users discussed films like Total Recall, a title shared by the 1990 and 2012 sci-fi movies, also echoing the name of the French oil and gas giant Total. Some users humorously altered film titles to reflect the fuel shortage, such as changing Pulp Fiction to Pump Friction, The Full Monty to The Fuel Monty, and renaming Mad Max: Fury Road to Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane. Vin Diesel's last name and his Fast and Furious franchise inspired creative titles like Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious (meaning Not Fast But Furious), Immobile and Furious, and Fuel Furious. Others reimagined 8 Mile, starring Eminem, as 0 Mile and 8 Miles a Pied (8 Miles on Foot). Stanley Kubrick's work led to Fuel Metal Jacket, a play on his film Full Metal Jacket. The French title for Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, 2001, l'Odyssee de l'espace, inspired wordplay with Renault's Espace minivan model. Images of people filling jerrycans at stations sparked titles like Tom and Jerrycan, Jerrycan Beauty, and Catch Me If You Jerrycan. Nicolas Winding Refn's film Drive was amusingly renamed Walk and Drive Pas. Read more about France's debated new labor laws.

Immigration Minister Peter Dutton reported that a 17-year-old was recently stopped at Sydney airport two weeks ago. Mr. Dutton noted an increasing danger from Australians trying to join organizations like Islamic State (IS). In August, special anti-terror teams were deployed at Australia's eight international airports. The teenager, heading to the Middle East conflict, was returned to his parents' care as investigations proceeded, according to Mr. Dutton. This interception occurred about a week after two Sydney brothers, ages 16 and 17, were similarly detained at the same airport for allegedly attempting to join IS. These brothers, whose identities remain undisclosed, were also handed back to their parents. Australian media reports indicate that despite some parental concerns, the students have been permitted to continue their education at a prestigious Sydney high school. Australia's anti-terrorism units have engaged with 85,000 individuals at airports nationwide since August, Mr. Dutton stated. Australia believes roughly 90 citizens have traveled to Iraq or Syria to fight with IS, with 20 known fatalities. Unconfirmed reports suggest Melbourne teenager Jake Bilardi committed a suicide attack in Syria earlier this month after joining IS. His father, John Bilardi, in an interview with Australia's 60 Minutes, described his son as a "loner" with a "death wish," treated by IS as a "prize." "He was a trophy they showcased online, boasting about recruiting a young boy without a Muslim background," Mr. Bilardi remarked. In Australia, it is illegal for citizens to enter IS strongholds like Mosul and Raqqa without a valid reason, such as visiting family. Those who do risk a 10-year prison sentence.

The amnesty is intended for offenses committed during the political unrest following Mr. Thaksin's removal in a coup. Early on Friday, the lower house passed the contentious bill, which now moves to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has cautioned that its passage could spark street protests. Although they abstained from the vote, the bill was approved 310-0. According to BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, its approval in the Senate is uncertain as half of its members are appointed. Nonetheless, this could occur as soon as next week and is likely to incite further protests. Supporters of the bill argue it will help mend the political divide resulting from the 2006 military coup that ousted Mr. Thaksin, leading to deep divisions in Thailand. This unrest included the occupation of Bangkok's airport in 2008 and two months of protests in 2010, which resulted in approximately 90 deaths, primarily civilian protesters. Opponents argue the amnesty would permit human rights violations to go unpunished. Brad Adams, Asia director of Human Rights Watch, stated on October 21, "The proposed amnesty would allow officials and protest leaders with blood on their hands to escape punishment. By erasing past abuses, the government denies justice to victims and signals future abusers they have little to fear." The opposition suspects the bill is designed to ease Mr. Thaksin's return without serving a prison sentence. Thaksin Shinawatra has been in self-imposed exile overseas since a 2008 corruption conviction, which he claims was politically driven. Initially covering only ordinary protesters involved in street clashes, the amnesty was unexpectedly broadened two weeks ago to include anyone investigated by post-coup agencies. Mr. Thaksin's conviction was the result of one such investigation, our correspondent notes. Despite the coup, Mr. Thaksin remains popular with rural voters, and elections since have seen his allied parties elected. His sister, Yingluck Shinawatra, is now the prime minister. The opposition intends to contest the law. "We will continue our street protests until the bill is withdrawn. Other options include petitioning the Constitutional Court," stated Democrat Party spokesman Chavanond Intarakomalyasut. On Thursday, while the bill was under debate, thousands protested against it outside a railway station.

In the upcoming years, Forest Enterprise Scotland plans to plant trees around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley, aiming to foster approximately 600,000 young trees and establish a "large and vibrant habitat." Environment forester Gareth Ventress noted that upon realizing they were facing a "bumper crop" of acorns, they immediately began organizing their collection. Ventress mentioned they sought assistance from staff across Scotland to gather acorns from native oak woods on the national forest estate. The Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust, and Moffat Community Woodlands also participated in this extensive collection to promote native woodland expansion in southern Scotland. By utilizing acorns from various parts of Galloway Forest Park, the genetic diversity of the trees is enhanced, which is crucial for creating robust woodlands capable of withstanding pests and diseases in the future. The collection process involves spreading large felt nets on the forest floor to keep the acorns off the soil and facilitate easier gathering. After collection, the acorns are sorted and stored. Over the next three to four years, the acorn seeds will be germinated and cultivated, though many will be "graded" and deemed infertile during this period. An estimated 600,000 saplings are expected to be produced, contributing to new oak woods and enhancing woodland habitats throughout Galloway Forest Park.

Mr. Carney emphasized that securing long-term funding for green initiatives in developing countries can enhance financial stability. During a speech in Berlin, he encouraged Germany to utilize its G20 leadership in 2017 to advance these efforts. He has consistently highlighted the financial sector's climate change risks. On Thursday, Mr. Carney noted that, ideally, capital should move from developed to emerging markets due to high returns, but in reality, it's often the reverse, which has depressed bond yields in developed nations. He mentioned that intermittent capital flows to emerging markets have created instability. "In this scenario, green finance offers a significant opportunity. Directing capital towards long-term projects in countries with high carbon output can bolster financial stability," he stated. Mr. Carney pointed out that green bond issuance, meant for projects like water and renewable energy to cut carbon emissions, could potentially double in 2016 from last year's $42 billion, yet they still account for only 1% of global financial holdings. "Developing this new global asset class is key to promoting a low-carbon future, boosting global investment, and driving growth," he remarked. He discussed a dilemma: by the time economic incentives to combat climate change become clear, action may be too late. Additionally, he warned that a swift shift to a low-carbon economy might harm financial stability. In transitioning to this economy, Mr. Carney urged companies to reveal how climate change could impact their business models. He has previously cautioned about the finance sector's climate risks, such as the potential for many fossil fuel reserves to become non-viable if governments act to curb global warming.

Gene Palmer is the second prison worker arrested in connection with the jailbreak. Joyce Mitchell has already been accused of assisting with the escape. Richard Matt and David Sweat, the prisoners, used power tools to break out of the Clinton Correctional Facility. A large-scale search is ongoing to locate the two, who are both convicted murderers. Mr. Palmer is being held on bail after facing charges of promoting prison contraband, tampering with evidence, and official misconduct. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, acknowledged that his client delivered the meat but claimed he was unaware it contained tools or that the inmates were planning to escape. "He did pass the hamburger meat. He shouldn't have done it. He apologized for it," said Mr. Brockway, noting that his client intends to plead not guilty. Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie explained that Ms. Mitchell hid hacksaw blades and other tools in the meat, which Mr. Palmer then delivered to Matt and Sweat, who were housed in a part of the prison where inmates can prepare their own meals. Meanwhile, authorities are focusing their search on a 75-square-mile area in northern New York. Police found evidence that the two men had stayed at a hunting cabin near the prison, and they are believed to possibly be armed due to the area's abundance of weapons. "They are extremely dangerous, they're cunning," said New York State Police Major Charles Guess. "Why wouldn't they try to arm themselves immediately upon escape?"

The party's election manifesto indicated that a funding floor would be implemented only after a referendum was initiated. The St David's Day Agreement had expressed that a vote was an "expectation," but Labour Welsh ministers disagreed with holding a referendum ahead of a funding deal. Labour accused the Conservatives of pressuring them unfairly. The manifesto states the Conservatives plan to "introduce a 'funding floor' to safeguard Welsh funding and provide certainty for future planning by the Welsh Government, once a referendum on Income Tax powers is called in the next Parliament." However, a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman clarified to BBC Wales: "Our commitment to a funding floor for Wales is firm and unequivocal, with ongoing efforts at the Treasury and the Wales Office to implement it. The funding floor is not dependent on an income tax referendum. Our UK manifesto clarifies our expectation for the Welsh Assembly to hold an early referendum on income tax powers in the next Parliament. More details of our ambitious plans for Wales will be revealed in the Conservative Party Welsh Manifesto launching later this week." Chancellor George Osborne mentioned to BBC Wales on Friday that the funding floor per head would be between £113 and £116 for every £100 spent in England, aligning with economist Gerry Holtham's recommendation. Labour also intends to introduce a funding floor for the Welsh government but has not specified an amount. Responding to the Conservative manifesto, First Minister Carwyn Jones stated: "Voting for the Tories means supporting a government that could cost Wales up to £300m annually. A fair funding settlement must be truly fair - conditions cannot be imposed or used as leverage." The Liberal Democrats propose commissioning an independent review of Wales' funding to consider increasing the budget. Plaid Cymru seeks an additional £1.2bn annually for the Welsh government, claiming it would match Scottish spending levels. UKIP suggests abolishing the current Barnett formula that allocates funding among the four UK nations.

Hibernian suffered a heavy 10-1 aggregate defeat to Bayern Munich, while Glasgow City were beaten 3-1 by Sweden's Eskilstuna United. Signeul told BBC Scotland that having two Scottish teams in the Champions League is a great achievement for Scottish football, highlighting that their efforts have earned them two spots. She noted that the Netherlands, hosts of Euro 2017 and opponents for Scotland in an October 20 friendly in Livingston, only have one team in the top European competition. This success, she explained, is due to the rankings built by Glasgow City and the national team. Hibs were making their first appearance in the knockout stage, and Signeul emphasized the challenge they faced against title contenders Bayern Munich, who boast a squad of full-time professionals from various national teams. Bayern's squad included the Olympic golden boot winner, making it a tough matchup. Signeul believes this experience helps Hibs players understand the level they need to reach, contrasting it with international games where teams might overestimate their abilities against weaker opponents. Despite being Scottish champions for nine years, Glasgow City's hope of advancing was dashed by the strong performance of Eskilstuna, who narrowly outplayed them. Signeul also commented on the situation of Gordon Strachan, the men's national team coach, whose future was in doubt after mixed World Cup qualifier results. She argued that comparing his challenges to her team's success was unfair, as women's football often reflects rankings more closely, whereas men's football is more competitive and unpredictable. She affirmed her belief in Strachan's continued support from his players.

Instead of owning cars and bikes, one possible future envisions us renting transportation for travel. This idea gained momentum this week in the capital with the launch of oBike, a company supported by significant venture capital. They're deploying hundreds of rental bikes across London's streets, aiming for thousands by summer's end, following their massive operations in South East Asia. Unlike existing cycle hire schemes, these bikes have no docking stations; they feature a locking rear brake allowing them to be left anywhere. Users can access them through an app, locating bikes via GPS. There is a refundable deposit of £49, and the cost is 50p per half-hour. More companies are likely to join this trend. oBike intends to complement the current scheme and has a mission to improve London's air quality and lower emissions. They hope to collaborate with Transport for London (TfL) and local councils, but this has yet to materialize. Some councils are upset about the lack of consultation and the sudden appearance of bikes in their areas. Hackney Council, while generally supportive of cycle hire, worries that oBike's can be left anywhere, causing obstructions. The council from east London mentioned no communication with the company. In Hammersmith & Fulham, about 400 oBikes appeared without notice, worrying the west London council. "We're very much in favor of cycling," stated Cllr Stephen Cowan, leader of the council. "But we expect companies to consult us first. This launch could have been better planned." oBike agreed to remove its bikes from the borough. In London, we've seen conflicts between authorities and new tech companies before. City Hall's response has been cautious. London's Walking and Cycling Commissioner, Will Norman, stated, "We need dock-less bike operators to work with TfL and borough councils to ensure these bikes benefit all Londoners without negatively affecting other cyclists, road users, and pedestrians. These schemes have great potential to make cycling more accessible, but they must be introduced in a way that suits our capital."

On Wednesday, the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee announced Gabon as the host for the 2017 Nations Cup, chosen over Ghana and Algeria. "We aim to win the Nations Cup in 2017," stated Gabon football official Jean-Felix Mba Nze. "Our goal is to compete and secure the cup." Gabon first entered the Nations Cup in 1970 but didn't qualify for the finals until 1994. Their top performances were making it to the quarter-finals in 1996 and 2012, during which they co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. This year, in a tournament also held in Equatorial Guinea, Gabon exited early after winning one and losing two group stage matches. The 2017 event will mark the first time Gabon hosts the finals independently. "Our primary challenge is to organise a better event than in 2012," Mba Nze, the secretary general of the Gabonese federation, told BBC Sport. "I believe we succeeded in our bid due to our strong presentation and improvements in stadiums, hospitals, and media facilities. We are more advanced than during the last Nations Cup." Gabon will reuse two stadiums from the 2012 finals—one in Libreville with a capacity of 45,000, and another in Franceville with 25,000—and introduce two new venues. The new stadiums in Port Gentil and Oyem, each accommodating 20,000, are expected to be ready by August 2016, five months before the tournament starts. Gabon's selection was met with dissatisfaction from the other candidate countries. The Algerian media criticized the outcome, with Algeria Soir calling it a 'sporting and political setback for Algeria,' while El Watan blamed insufficient political backing for their bid. Meanwhile, Ghana's bid team expressed surprise at the announcement, calling for more transparency in the selection process and questioning why the Confederation of African Football (Caf) did not disclose the voting results. Caf responded by noting that voting results were not revealed during the announcements of host countries for the 2019, 2021, and 2023 Nations Cups last September.

On average, they spend £581 annually on music festivals, often choosing VIP passes or enhanced camping options. These "superfans," who are mostly male, are more inclined than general consumers to purchase music on CDs or as downloads. This insight comes from a survey of 504 UK residents who attended at least one festival in the past year. According to Eventbrite, the ticketing platform that conducted the survey, these superfans play a crucial role in "driving the music festivals market," frequently recommending music and events to friends. Representing 28% of the festival audience, over half (54%) say they would attend an event alone. Typically, they spend £45 more per event than casual fans, but their loyalty is uncertain, as 46% believe festivals are becoming "too corporate." The UK hosts over 100 music festivals annually, from major events like Glastonbury and T In The Park to smaller ones such as the Cambridge Jazz Festival and Jamie Oliver's Big Feastival. Annually, 3.7 million people attend festivals, contributing to over 39,000 full-time jobs, according to Music UK. Despite this, small profit margins and market saturation have led some events to struggle. In the rainy summer of 2012, 57 festivals were canceled, including Oxegen and The Big Chill. Although the closure rate has slowed, several events such as the Temples festival in Bristol, Down To The Woods in Sedgefield, and Field Day in Tunbridge Wells were canceled this year, and Sonisphere did not return after a planned break in 2015. However, recent research provides some comfort to organizers, with 88% of respondents planning to attend festivals again next year, and more than half intending to attend more. "It's been a challenging year for some festivals, with adverse weather, economic uncertainties post-Brexit, rising costs, and increased security concerns," said Paul Reed, head of the Association of Independent Festivals. "This research shows that the sector remains robust, with resilient promoters dedicated to creating unforgettable experiences for audiences eager to return to their favorite events annually." Over the weekend, Cromer recorded 37 crimes, including the rape of a teenager, with residents associating the incidents with a group of travelers. Suffolk Constabulary had alerted Norfolk Police about this group before their arrival on Friday. Norfolk acknowledged receiving the warning and stated it was reviewing its response. Suffolk officers had informed their Norfolk counterparts about the travelers after they were issued a notice to leave Lowestoft on Friday due to various disturbances in the town. Norfolk confirmed they had been notified but mentioned there was "no intelligence to suggest the group's destination." On Friday, a young woman was raped at a bus stop on Cadogan Road, near the seafront. Norfolk Police suggested this could be linked to the town's disorder. One man was arrested and released under investigation regarding the rape, with no further arrests made. On Saturday night, a BBC reporter learned from a taxi driver that "travelers are rampaging the town," and staff at The Wellington pub reported closing after a group of 30 travelers became "rowdy." Lee Sale, an ice cream shop owner, mentioned travelers had alarmed families with "intimidating behavior." Ayrun Nessa, whose husband owns the Masala Twist restaurant, described being confronted at the door by six women shouting abuse. Cromer's Safer Neighbourhood Team is holding police surgeries to allow residents to express their concerns. Up to 25 travelers' caravans arrived at Runton Road's cliff-top car park on Friday but have since departed.

In August of last year, a pilot of an A320 reported a white quadcopter drone sped past their aircraft while flying south of Brookmans Park. The UK Airprox Board noted that there was no time for evasive action, and their report determined that a collision was narrowly avoided, largely due to chance. According to air traffic control, the pilot mentioned at around 18:45 BST on 15 August 2016, that "something had just gone over the top" while flying north of Potters Bar. Although another aircraft was nearby, the pilot described the object as being red and white, with red and blue stripes on two rotor arms, and less than a meter in size. Drone operators are mandated by the Air Navigation Order (ANO) 2016 to ensure flights are safe and not endanger anyone or anything, and must keep "direct, unaided visual contact" to track the drone's path relative to other aircraft. The Airprox board concluded that the drone was flying beyond the permitted line-of-sight without Civil Aviation Authority approval, thereby conflicting with the A320's flight path. The drone operator remains unidentified.

A study involving employees and managers revealed that 25% of new fathers opted out of taking any paternity leave, and fewer than 10% took more than the statutory two weeks. The Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) attributed this to entrenched employer attitudes and financial concerns from fathers about affording the time off. Last year, the government proposed changes to allow shared maternity and paternity leave, set to begin in April 2015. However, the ILM indicated these changes might be ineffective unless employer attitudes also change. Charles Elvin, ILM's chief executive, stated, "Shared parental leave is vital for advancing women into senior roles." He added that their research highlighted cultural barriers hindering the use of both statutory and additional paternity leave. Elvin noted a prevailing expectation in organizations that women, not men, would take longer leave. The report also pointed to low paternity pay as a deterrent, with only 9% of fathers receiving more than two weeks of full pay. Responding to the findings, Frances O'Grady, TUC's secretary general, emphasized pay as a key issue, noting that many fathers can't afford time off as employers seldom supplement statutory pay. Currently, employed fathers can take one or two weeks of paid leave, plus extra if the mother returns to work without claiming maternity pay. The government's plan aims to enhance flexibility, allowing parents to share their leave. A government spokesperson commented, "We aim to create a cultural shift with shared parental leave, enabling working dads to be more involved in their child's early months." They added that employers could benefit by retaining talented women and fostering a more motivated workforce.

As with the previous year's parade, only the Orangemen and their 13 pre-approved bands are allowed to march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast. They must do so with just a single drum beat. This year, all music must cease 43 meters from the church to ensure it is not heard nearby. Additionally, a planned protest by residents is limited to 50 people at two locations. The Orange Order expressed outrage at this decision, stating that "the commission now merely echoes republican propaganda, letting them set the conditions for loyal order parades." They criticized the new rule prohibiting music within 'earshot' of an unused place of worship as absurd and a clear attempt to restrict Protestant heritage on Northern Ireland's supposed shared streets. North Belfast MP Nigel Dodds from the DUP remarked that the latest decision on Donegall Street shows the Parades Commission as a bureaucratic entity that is out of control, seemingly pandering to republican residents or dangerously doing both. "It’s alarming the Commission seriously considered banning music outside Clifton Street Orange hall. It's not a joke." In contrast, SDLP assembly member Alban Maginness supported the decision, calling it sensible and hoping it sets a respectful tone for the marching season. "Throughout this dispute, St Patrick's parishioners and Carrick Hill residents have simply asked for respect," he stated.

The 34-year-old midfielder recently concluded his stint in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. McFadden, who has returned to play multiple times, explained, "I understand the attraction and why one would want to come back." He confirmed that Motherwell has extended an offer to him. "I know Pearo feels the same way," he said. Pearson started his career at Fir Park and, after playing for Celtic, Derby County, Bristol City, and Karela Blasters, returned to Well for a season in 2015. Now a free agent, he helped Kolkata secure a fourth-place finish in the Indian league before clinching the title with a play-off win over Karela. "We've spoken to him and made an offer, and we're waiting for his response," said McFadden, noting Motherwell's tradition of welcoming former players back. "Pearo would greatly benefit us both on and off the field. We'd love to have him back and hope he makes the right choice. I know he has a few things to consider, but he knows he'll be welcomed with open arms." Motherwell has signed winger Elliot Frear from Forest Green, and added Reading defender Zak Jules and Everton goalkeeper Russell Griffiths on loan recently. They continue to seek new additions before the transfer window closes. "We are working on it," McFadden added. "However, we haven't received responses from the players we're in discussions with, so we'll see what happens."

In February 1997, the body of 24-year-old Kevin Mcleod was discovered in Wick harbour. Although his death was initially considered accidental, his family suspects he was murdered due to injuries observed on his body. Following interactions between his family and chief constable Phil Gormley, a thorough assessment of "all information known" about the case was conducted. This review involved tracing and interviewing individuals present in Wick the night Mr. Mcleod died, who had not previously come forward. Last month, Mr. Mcleod's mother, June, told BBC Scotland that if the assessment revealed "nothing new," their family would persist in seeking a new investigation. Additionally, the chief constable ordered a separate evaluation concerning the police's handling of the family's complaints about the investigation since 1997. Detective Chief Superintendent Gareth Blair, head of major crime at Police Scotland, explained the assessment was done "in recognition of the continued impact" of Mr. Mcleod's death on his parents and "their desire for a conclusive outcome." He stated, "Our sympathies remain with them. "This was not a full reinvestigation of the death, but a detailed analysis of a significant amount of information linked to the circumstances since 1997." Specialist officers from Police Scotland's major crime command conducted this work, which included locating and interviewing witnesses in Wick that night who had not yet come forward. Det Ch Supt Blair informed Mr. Mcleod's parents on Tuesday about the assessment's conclusion. He stated, "I informed Kevin's parents that the assessment found no evidence of criminality, and the cause of his death remains unexplained, providing no basis for a full reinvestigation. "Police Scotland encourages anyone with information about Kevin's death to come forward, promising to thoroughly consider any new evidence. "The chief constable has tasked the head of professional standards with carrying out a separate review to ensure all issues and complaints raised by the family over the years have been properly addressed."

Matthew Eteson is facing trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton. The two died while sleeping on a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Eteson, 42, from Hale, Greater Manchester, denies the charge. The family had traveled to the Lake District to celebrate a friend's birthday over the Easter bank holiday weekend. On the afternoon of April 1, Eteson removed a generator from the deck to power a 1kW fan heater for the sleeping area, according to prosecutor Graham Reeds QC. The court heard that toxic gas accumulated without warning because the carbon monoxide sensors had been disabled prior. Reeds stated that the mother and daughter, both from Leyland, Lancashire, were discovered dead in their sleeping positions on the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser Arniston, with lethal carbon monoxide levels in their systems. Eteson, who had slept in a different compartment further from the generator, also suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning but awoke to find their bodies. The court was informed that Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had modified the generator and its exhaust, which experts later found to be "dangerous." Nia Webster, Kelly's mother, had previously questioned Eteson about carbon monoxide sensors. He replied that they were non-functional and mentioned that his partner would unplug a portable detector when cooking. The trial is ongoing.

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) emphasized the importance of O negative blood, as it can be used for patients of different blood types during emergencies. Although only 7% of the UK population has O negative blood, it accounts for 12% of blood transfusions. Additionally, B negative blood is crucial for ethnic groups. NHSBT noted that ethnic minorities, who are more likely to have B negative blood, are at greater risk of sickle cell anemia, a condition where deformed blood cells can block vessels, leading to premature death. These groups are also more susceptible to thalassemia, an inherited disorder affecting oxygen transport in the blood. Only 2% of the UK population has B negative blood, but its use in hospitals increased by 6% over the past month compared to the same period last year. B negative blood is beneficial for both B negative and B positive patients. Donna Batty, NHSBT's donor relations manager, urged donors to come forward soon, noting that stocks for "these vulnerable groups" are "lower than we would like." She encouraged donors with upcoming appointments to keep them, hoping they understand if there are longer waits. Currently, 4% of the UK population donates blood. Jon Latham, NHSBT's assistant director of marketing, expressed the desire for "first-time donors" to help expand their database, making it easier to reach out during specific needs. People unsure of their blood type can learn it after donating. Those interested in donating are encouraged to call NHSBT at 0300 123 23 23.

Dr. Stephen Farry, the Minister for Employment and Learning, has decided to cut a special premium payment of £1.1 million that was provided to compensate for the college's small size and specialized status. The college, with fewer than 1,000 students and an annual income of £4.7 million, is expected to lose 31% of its budget due to the removal of this premium and overall reductions in Department of Employment and Learning (DEL) funding, according to protesters. However, the announcement of an additional £32 million for the DEL in the latest budget somewhat alleviates the situation. With this extra funding, the college expects a budget cut of 26.5%, which, while slightly better, remains very challenging, according to the principal, Prof. Peter Finn. He accuses Stephen Farry of making an opportunistic decision to push the college towards one of the proposed solutions for restructuring teacher training in Northern Ireland. None of the four proposed options allow St. Mary's to maintain its current autonomy. The college is committed to preserving its character and Catholic values. Prof. Finn supports "very deep sharing" between teacher training institutions, potentially allowing students to attend classes at different colleges. He strongly opposes the idea that small scale and specialist premiums should be removed simply because they don't exist elsewhere in Northern Ireland. While he acknowledges similar payments were removed in England, he points out that English institutions were then allowed to charge higher tuition fees and had no student intake restrictions, freedoms not granted to St. Mary's. Stranmillis University College, which primarily trains non-Catholic school teachers, faces similar challenges but has been in talks to merge with Queen's University since 2008. This merger has faced opposition and remains unapproved, and the funding cuts and removal of premiums would also impact Stranmillis.

The Welsh government is providing nearly £15 million to support an investment with production set to begin in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart highlighted the deal's importance, noting it would "safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs for many years." She emphasized the effort to attract this investment to Wales amid global competition. Ford’s choice to produce its new innovative engine in Wales reflects the strong reputation of the local management and the dedication of the Welsh workforce, she stated. The Ford plant in Bridgend, operational since 1980, has consistently secured investments totaling over £2.8 billion despite intense competition. Ford’s presence in south Wales is significant, supporting about 10,000 jobs, with 1,860 employed directly at the plant. Engineers from Essex and Germany collaborated on designing a new range of fuel-efficient engines. A letter from Ford to employees in June, seen by the BBC, mentioned that changes in working conditions at Bridgend would be needed to secure the investment and enhance competitiveness. William Graham, Welsh Conservative shadow economy minister, remarked that the announcement indicated "confidence in the UK government's efforts to rebuild the economy." This development is positive news for Bridgend workers, as new production will start in 2018 just as Jaguar Land Rover engine manufacturing ends, preserving hundreds of jobs that might otherwise be lost. Earlier this year, 200 fixed contract workers were laid off when the plant ceased making engines for Volvo. However, concerns remain that the new investment may lead Bridgend to produce only a third of its current engine output. Some question the rationale behind the Welsh government investing £15 million in a multinational’s own plant. Bridgend competed with three other European Ford plants for this work, each receiving government financial support. The global competitiveness of the automotive industry necessitates such backing to prevent companies from relocating.

S4C primarily relies on funding from the licence fee, and UK ministers have initiated a significant review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies expressed to BBC Wales that S4C is a "special case" because it supports the Welsh language. Ministers have suggested that S4C should pursue cost reductions similar to those of the BBC. On Thursday, Labour cautioned that reducing the BBC's budget could impact S4C, but Culture Secretary John Whittingdale assured MPs of a commitment to the channel "in the coming years" and expressed a desire to engage in discussions with its management soon. Speaking to BBC Radio Cymru's Rhaglen Dylan Jones on Friday, Mr. Davies remarked, "The government understands the significance of S4C, recognizing it as more than just a station, but as crucial to the future of the Welsh language." He also indicated that the Welsh Affairs Committee, which he leads, might explore an inquiry into broadcasting, including S4C. "These are my personal views, but I consider S4C a special case for promoting the Welsh language and believe it is more vital for S4C to continue than any other BBC channel," he added. S4C has reported experiencing "substantial cuts" since 2010 and plans to highlight the "uniqueness" of its service and its "cultural and economic value" during discussions with ministers. A green paper on the BBC's future released on Thursday mentioned that "audience reach has been decreasing for some indigenous language services in recent years, especially in Wales." It also pointed out that the higher cost of Welsh-language radio programming compared to English-language content "raises concerns about value for money".

The recent Markit Report on Jobs for Scotland highlighted a significant increase in both permanent and temporary job placements in April, with demand for temporary staff reaching its highest level in nearly ten years. Despite this growth, recruiters expressed concerns about a decrease in candidate availability, which poses a challenge for employers trying to secure needed skills. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC) emphasized that the incoming government post the June 8 general election must ensure access to necessary foreign workers and invest in UK jobseekers. The report noted that April marked the third consecutive month of growth in permanent appointments, achieving the fastest expansion rate in 21 months, contrasting with a general slowdown across the UK. Temporary placements also saw the steepest rise since August 2014. However, April experienced a sharp decline in worker availability, particularly in permanent staff, recording the largest drop in nine months. Temporary candidate availability in Scotland decreased at the fastest rate in nearly two years. The IT and computing, nursing/medical/care, and hotel and catering sectors experienced the highest demand for permanent staff, while nursing/medical/care, IT and computing, and engineering and construction sectors led in temporary staff demand. Additionally, the report showed a significant increase in average salaries for permanent starters in Scotland and the fastest rise in temporary pay in a year. REC chief executive Kevin Green remarked on the continued recovery of the Scottish job market, noting the high demand for temporary staff as companies navigate Brexit uncertainties and consumer needs. He welcomed the rise in starting salaries for permanent roles but warned that decreasing candidate availability could hinder success. Green urged the future government to address the shrinking pool of candidates by investing in skills and career advice for UK jobseekers and ensuring access to international workers. He stressed the importance of a flexible future immigration system that adapts to changing labor market requirements.

Envoy Sigrid Kaag addressed the situation as Syria seemed to miss a Sunday deadline for removing its chemical arsenal. All of Syria's chemical weapons are slated for destruction by June 30. The US-Russia agreement to dismantle Syria's stockpile was established last year following a sarin rocket attack near Damascus that resulted in hundreds of casualties. The multinational effort to eliminate these weapons is managed by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). Despite the UN's June 30 deadline for total destruction, Syria had committed to completing its stockpile removal by April 27 after previously missing several deadlines. "The majority of the chemical weapons material has been removed but not yet destroyed, which aligns with the June 30 deadline," explained Ms. Kaag, leader of the OPCW-UN Joint Mission, to the BBC. She highlighted the importance of retrieving the remaining materials located at a single site. Additionally, Ms. Kaag expressed concern over reports of Syrian forces allegedly using chlorine gas as a weapon. Chlorine was not included in the original deal, which many believe prevented US military intervention against the Syrian government. Damascus has denied the use of chlorine gas. The OPCW notes that most of Syria's chemical weapons are stored as separate components that form lethal agents when combined. Ms. Kaag confirmed that the necessary facilities for producing, preparing, and launching chemical weapon attacks have been dismantled. "What remains are the components of a chemical weapon, but Syria's chemical weapons program, according to their current declaration under the Chemical Weapons Convention, no longer exists," she stated.

She outperformed a shortlist including Gaelle Enganamouit (FC Rosengard, Sweden), Amandine Henry (Olympique Lyonnais), Carli Lloyd (Houston Dash), and Becky Sauerbrunn (FC Kansas City). "I'm surprised and extremely humbled to win," said the 25-year-old Little. "Women's football is thriving. Hopefully, it will continue to grow." Little was Seattle's top scorer and the second overall in the U.S. National Women's Soccer League, with 10 goals, aiding the Reign in leading the league in 2015. She also played on loan for Melbourne City that year. The former Hibernian and Arsenal Ladies star—a five-time title winner with the Gunners—has 115 caps for Scotland, scoring 46 goals. In 2012, the Aberdeen-born player helped Great Britain reach the quarter-finals at the London Olympics. She was named the FA's Women's Player of the Year in 2010 and was the inaugural PFA Women's Players' Player of the Year in 2013. "She's a player with nearly everything," commented Scotland coach Anna Signeul. "Her speed, balance, and pitch movement are fantastic. Her technique is brilliant; there are few things she can't do. She's a role model, perfect on and off the pitch, and it might be a long time before Scotland sees another player like her."
