On 30 January 1915, a charity match between England and Scotland was organized by Edgar Mobbs, a former England international and captain of Northampton Saints. The match aimed to recruit sportsmen for Mobbs's World War One battalion. A commemorative game is scheduled for 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club, featuring players from the East Midlands against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, while Olney Ladies will compete against the Army Women's XV. Edgar Mobbs, born in Northampton in 1882, began his career in Olney and became captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907. He was selected for England in 1909, scoring a try on his debut against Australia and earning seven caps. He rose from private to battalion commander, fighting in key battles like Loos, Somme, Arras, and Messines, receiving the Distinguished Service Order and being mentioned in Despatches twice. Mobbs died on 31 July 1917 during the battle of Passchendaele while charging a German machine gun. After retiring from rugby in 1913 at age 30, Mobbs was initially denied an officer's commission due to age but enlisted as a private. He actively encouraged enlistment, once addressing a large crowd at a Northampton Saints game, and helped recruit over 200 men. The 1915 international match reportedly inspired many to join his Sportsman's Battalion, a major component of the 7th Battalion of the Northamptonshire Regiment, including 16 Olney players who later died in the war. Mobbs's family members, including his great-nephew also named Edgar Mobbs, will attend the upcoming game, echoing MP Ryland Adkins's sentiment that "Northamptonshire in time of peace produced no finer sportsman and in time of war no finer soldier." Jarlath McElroy, chairman of Olney Rugby Club, described Mobbs as a "sporting and war hero." Proceeds from the event will benefit the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association military charity.

The newly established charity will oversee the National Heritage Collection, which encompasses Stonehenge and Dover Castle. Currently, the government provides an annual contribution of £22m to support the collection. The goal is for the charity to eventually achieve financial independence. Funding responsibilities for tasks such as building listings will remain with the government. The new advisory body on planning is tentatively named the National Heritage Protection Service. The charity will continue to be known as English Heritage, and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection, including Kenwood House in London and Charles Darwin's home in Kent, will stay publicly owned. Government funding for the charity will gradually decrease from 2015 until it ceases, allowing the charity greater liberty to pursue revenue through commercial ventures and donations. Part of the £80m government grant will aid in establishing the charity to ensure full functionality by March 2015. A government agency described these proposed changes, pending consultation, as "an excellent outcome." "This year, we are celebrating a century of state protection for heritage, and today’s announcement lays the groundwork for the next century. The government's £80m investment and the new charity's formation will assist in preserving the National Heritage Collection, uphold the authenticity of the sites we manage, strive for excellence in our conservation efforts and event management, and enhance experiences that vividly tell England's story." This announcement coincided with government plans to reduce funding for museums and the arts by up to 5% in the 2015-2016 Spending Review.

Christopher Kelly, 40, strangled his friend Dorothy Beattie, 51, at her Dunoon, Argyll and Bute home on May 22. The High Court in Glasgow was informed that his attack followed an alleged insult about his children. Kelly, who was apprehended after confessing to a GP, initially faced a murder charge but admitted to the lesser offense of culpable homicide. The court learned Kelly was once a support worker for Ms. Beattie, who had numerous medical issues, including seizures. The two, later friends, often spent time together socially. However, following alleged "derogatory" comments about his children, Kelly attacked Ms. Beattie in her home, strangling her before leaving. He later returned, found her dead, sat with the body, moved it to the bed, and fled. The court heard Kelly used Ms. Beattie's bank card to withdraw £300, then took a train to Edinburgh. Her daughter discovered the body on May 25 after losing contact. Kelly reportedly slept on the streets until May 28 when he visited a GP and confessed, stating: "Something bad has happened. I think I killed her." He recounted remembering a "fight" and "grabbing her around the neck" before blacking out, later realizing she was dead. He moved her to the bed and left. Kelly added, "We're just pals - I had been her support worker." Police were contacted, and Kelly described the recent days as "torture." The court heard that Ms. Beattie's injuries suggested "significant force." Judge Lord Bannatyne noted the sentence would have been seven years, reduced due to Kelly's guilty plea, calling it a "tragic case." Kelly mouthed "sorry" to the victim's two daughters as he was led away in handcuffs.

On April 3, shortly after 15:30 BST, a train traveling from Penzance to Exeter collided with another train on platform six. Initial findings by the Rail Accident Investigation Branch revealed the signaller thought both trains could fit on the platform. Approximately 35 people sustained injuries. For ongoing updates, visit our Local Live pages. The report stated that "permissive working," which allows multiple trains to share a platform, is permitted for passenger trains on platform six. The signaller, from the signal box window, believed there was sufficient space for the moving train, which was incorrect. One train was directed to platform six because passenger lifts were under maintenance elsewhere. As the train neared Plymouth, it accelerated to around 21 mph and navigated a tight left-hand curve. At this point, the driver unexpectedly saw the stationary train's rear close to the platform's west end. The report noted: "He checked the tracks to verify the train's route and, realizing a collision was imminent, applied the emergency brake. This occurred roughly three seconds before the impact, which happened at approximately 15 mph. Many passengers, preparing to disembark, were thrown against the train's fixtures and onto the floor."

The 71-year-old secured 60.75% of the votes, with his closest competitor, Kizza Besigye, receiving 35%, according to the election commission. Supporters of Mr. Museveni argued that his opponents did not present any viable alternatives for progress. However, Mr. Besigye, currently under house arrest, denounced the results as a "sham" and urged the international community to reject them, stating, "We have just witnessed what must be the most fraudulent electoral process in Uganda." EU observers also criticized the election, noting the ruling party had fostered an "intimidating atmosphere" and faced accusations of vote rigging from the opposition. EU Chief Observer Eduard Kukan commended Ugandans for their "remarkable determination" to vote but noted that the National Resistance Movement's dominance distorted the campaign's fairness. The election process has been plagued by sporadic violence and allegations from the opposition of electoral fraud, alongside the blocking of social media and messaging apps. Police placed Mr. Besigye under house arrest on Friday, suspecting he would announce results independently, which would breach electoral laws. This marks the fourth attempt by Mr. Besigye, the candidate for the opposition Forum for Democratic Change, to challenge President Museveni. Once allies, Mr. Besigye served as Museveni's personal doctor during their time as guerrilla fighters. Since taking power in 1986, Mr. Museveni is recognized for restoring stability to Uganda, though critics accuse him of becoming increasingly authoritarian. The next closest contender, former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi, is also reportedly under house arrest as Uganda's veteran leaders employ new election strategies.

The retailer asserts that the Chippenham plans would generate 1,000 jobs and inject £31 million into the economy annually. Among the five candidates competing for the area's MP position, one opposes the plans entirely, while three express concerns about the proposed site. Thousands of local residents have signed petitions both supporting and opposing the development. Conservative candidate Michelle Donelan acknowledges both perspectives but criticizes the consultation process—now concluded—as insufficient for a project that will "dramatically change the town forever." Wiltshire Council has yet to review the application for the 72,000 sq m regional center, but the candidates shared their opinions during an election debate recorded by BBC Wiltshire. Labour's Andy Newman supports the development, having been assured it will create 700 permanent skilled jobs and boost local wages. Conversely, Green party candidate Tina Johnston opposes the plans, arguing the projected job numbers are overly optimistic. Two candidates, although supportive of the plans, doubt the suitability of the location. Julia Reid (UKIP) suggests it should be nearer the motorway and farther from the town to minimize impact on town center shops. Lastly, Liberal Democrat Duncan Hames appreciates the potential job opportunities but remains uncertain about the site's appropriateness.

The 31-year-old announced on Twitter that she was refused service by a black cab driver who told her to "find an immigrant" for a ride. This incident followed her apology "on behalf of my country" for the poor conditions at the Jungle camp in Calais. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association denounced the abusive conduct. She tweeted: "I tried to board a black cab with my kids. The driver said, 'find an immigrant to drive you, you stupid tart'." She later reflected: "Having lived a privileged life, this gave me a small insight into being discriminated against." Her claims faced skepticism. One Twitter user insisted it "definitely didn't happen," while another asked her for the taxi’s registration number. She accused them of "victim shaming," explaining: "I was holding my children and couldn't access my phone quickly." The association, representing around 5,500 black cabbies in London, urged Transport for London to investigate her claims. General secretary Steve McNamara stated: "It's uncertain if the driver was a member, but we treat such allegations with utmost seriousness and condemn any driver who behaves disrespectfully and uses offensive language. Such behavior risks their license." Earlier, Allen was emotional on the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire show while meeting Shamsher Sherin, a 13-year-old Afghan boy who had been at the migrant camp for two months before reuniting with his father in Birmingham. During their conversation, Allen expressed: "At multiple points in your life, the English have put you in harm's way. We've bombed your nation, subjected you to the Taliban, and now endangered your journey to our country. I apologize on behalf of my country for what we've done to you."

The terms of the deal for the 25-year-old World Cup runner-up remain undisclosed but are believed to be around £8m. The players we aim to bring in are those who enhance the squad's quality, and he certainly fits that mold. Fernandez has signed a four-year contract and is expected to join Swansea's squad for their match against Burnley on Saturday, pending international clearance. He started in four of Argentina's matches during their journey to the World Cup final. Fernandez arrives after manager Garry Monk sought to fill the gap left by 27-year-old Chico Flores, who moved to Qatar. The center-back expressed his excitement about joining the Swans after receiving advice from Michu. "Playing in the Premier League has always been a dream for me—it's the best in the world—and I'm thankful to Swansea for this opportunity," he said. "I consulted Michu and Jordi Amat about the club. I trained with Michu at Napoli and played alongside Alvaro Vazquez while on loan at Getafe in 2013. Vazquez is good friends with Jordi, so I spoke to them as well. "Michu described it as a family club in a relaxed city. He assured me I was joining a great club. Everything I've heard about Swansea has been positive." The Swans will host their first home Premier League game against Burnley on Saturday, 23 August, following their 2-1 victory over Manchester United. Fernandez has only recently resumed training after his World Cup campaign, so his readiness for the match is uncertain. Monk praised the defender, who made 13 appearances while on loan at Getafe last season, as a valuable addition to the club. "He brings experience from playing at the highest level with Napoli and Argentina in the World Cup. "His age is ideal for us, and his playing style complements Swansea City. "The players we seek are those who add quality to the squad, and he will undoubtedly do that."

Recently discovered CCTV footage shows Charlene Downes, 14, last seen in Blackpool town centre. Her body has never been located. Charlene's mother, Karen, expressed her frustration that this footage was only found now, despite years of investigations into the unsolved murder. Lancashire Police acknowledged Ms. Downes' concerns. No one has been convicted in relation to Charlene's death. The footage was released to mark the anniversary of Charlene's 2003 disappearance, part of the police force's "longest" murder investigation. Ms. Downes questioned why the footage wasn't found in earlier investigations, expressing both disgust and hope that it could now lead to answers. She said, "I want closure now... We can't move on with our lives and it's just terrible." Detective Chief Inspector Richard McCutcheon stated, "I can understand [the family's] views. We have just found the images and that's why we are publishing them now." The footage captures Charlene with her sister Rebecca on Bank Hey Street around 15:25 GMT on 1 November 2003, walking towards Coral Island amusement arcade. She returned home but later went back to Blackpool town centre that evening, which was the last time she was seen. Her clothes in the footage match those she was wearing when she disappeared. Detective Superintendent Andy Webster mentioned that the investigation is exploring connections between Charlene's disappearance and "child sexual exploitation" in Blackpool. He added, "We have identified several potential victims and offenders and are planning arrests and prosecutions soon." In 2008, a judge cleared a man of Charlene's murder due to "grave doubts" about the evidence in his second trial, after the first trial's jury couldn't reach a verdict. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) later criticized police for evidence-gathering mistakes that contributed to the retrial's collapse, citing strategic and tactical failures. Several officers faced disciplinary actions, with one forced to resign in 2011, although this was overturned by a 2012 Police Arbitration Tribunal.

Julia Knight, 56, is on trial at Oxford Crown Court, where she denies trying to murder Irene Robson, 81, at Banbury's Horton Hospital in October 2014. Although she admits to administering insulin, she claims her intention was to prevent Ms. Robson from being discharged. Knight also refutes charges of causing grievous bodily harm with intent, explaining she wanted her mother to stay under hospital care rather than return home. She expressed remorse, stating, "I felt terrible because I knew I was going to make mum unwell. It was a stupid, stupid thing to do. If I could go back and change it, I would." Knight admitted to lying to police during a January inquiry and revealed she had forged a prescription for insulin, which she picked up at a Sainsbury's in Banbury. When defense barrister Simon Mayo QC questioned why she denied injecting her mother to the police, Knight said, "I realised it was serious. I was ashamed of what I had done." Prosecutor John Price QC suggested she intended to deliver a fatal dose before departing the hospital, questioning her actions: "Why did you inject your mother with a substance which for all you knew could kill her within five minutes and do nothing for an hour and twenty minutes?" Knight answered, "I never intended my mother to die." She also disclosed a past suicide attempt in 2006 involving insulin injection. Although Ms. Robson passed away in September, the jury was informed earlier in the trial that her death was not related to the charges being considered. The trial is ongoing.

The Korea Space Launch Vehicle-1 (KSLV-1) launched from the Naro Space Center at 16:00 (07:00 GMT). According to Science Minister Lee Ju-ho, the satellite, aimed at gathering climate data, successfully entered its intended orbit. This launch follows North Korea's recent deployment of a satellite using a three-stage rocket, which drew global criticism. South Korea’s 140-tonne rocket, named Naro, was developed with Russian collaboration, allowing for three launch attempts. Past launches in 2009 and 2010 didn’t succeed, and this attempt had been delayed twice due to technical issues. However, officials confirmed that Wednesday’s launch from a site 480km (298 miles) south of Seoul proceeded smoothly, with the rocket achieving its target altitude and deploying the satellite. "The Naro rocket successfully placed the science satellite into the designated orbit after analyzing various data," Mr. Lee reported to the press. He mentioned that the satellite separated 540 seconds post-launch. "We have now advanced to become a space-power nation," he added, noting that South Korea intends to use this "overwhelming moment as a dynamic force" to propel its independent space program. The satellite, named Science and Technology Satellite-2C, is set to collect climate data. Yonhap news agency reported it was expected to contact its ground station by 05:00 on Thursday, at which point officials would confirm the launch's success. Although South Korea already has satellites in space, they were launched from other countries. In its first domestic launch attempt in 2009, the satellite failed to separate from the rocket. In 2010, the rocket exploded shortly after take-off. The pressure for a successful launch increased after North Korea launched a satellite into orbit on 12 December, subsequently announcing plans for a "high-level nuclear test" and more extended-range rocket launches. The UN deemed the North Korean launch an illegal missile technology test and extended sanctions against Pyongyang, with international appeals urging North Korea to refrain from conducting the nuclear test.

He warned he would resign from the Premier League club within 24 hours if the name change attempt fell through, and the Football Association rejected it in April. "When I say something, I mean it," the 75-year-old Egyptian declared on Thursday. He noted that the club was put up for sale 22 hours after the FA's decision five months ago. Allam mentioned that they were appealing the name change denial with the Court of Arbitration for Sport. "We stated earlier this year that the club would be for sale if our effort to promote Hull Tigers as a brand and playing name globally was blocked," he explained. "Following the FA's decision on 9 April, I announced on 10 April, within 22 hours, that Hull City is for sale." Allam, who took over the club in December 2010, was questioned about his plan if no buyer emerged and the legal appeal failed. "I will give it away. Out means I'm out. Have I ever said anything and gone back on it?" he remarked. Allam stated that he and his son Ehab, the club's acting chief executive, would remain committed to the club for the time being. "If the appeal comes first, ok, no harm done. If the sale comes first - sold," he said. He was vague about potential buyers' interest and suggested he might stay if the appeal succeeded. The chairman admitted that manager Steve Bruce and his players needed stability, but highlighted his investment during the transfer window, including the signing of Uruguay striker Abel Hernandez for a reported club record fee of £10m. Hull reached the FA Cup final last season, losing 3-2 to Arsenal after initially leading 2-0, and finished 16th in their first season back in the Premier League following promotion from the Championship. They are currently ninth in the table with four points from three matches in the new 2014-15 season.

Scot Higgins, aged 19, began his youth career at Celtic before transferring to Dens Park, where he appeared in four games for Dundee last season. Former Republic of Ireland Under-21 player Alan Power, 29, is departing English League Two's Lincoln City, where he made over 250 league appearances, to join the Rugby Park club. Both players have signed two-year contracts, with Power's transfer pending clearance. "I'm thrilled to be here, as it's a club clearly moving in the right direction," Higgins shared on Kilmarnock's website. Manager Lee McCulloch stated that Higgins aligns with Kilmarnock's focus on nurturing young talent. "He emerged from Celtic's academy, which has produced many notable young players," McCulloch noted. "His experience at Dundee last season will only enhance his growth, benefiting our club." Meanwhile, Power expressed, "I've learned a lot about the town and the club's legacy, and I'm eager to begin. The manager's vision for the club made the decision easy." McCulloch recalled watching Lincoln's journey to the FA Cup quarter-finals last season, highlighting Power's role: "Alan played in every match and was the club captain. His aggressive play style, desire for improvement, and substantial experience will be invaluable to our younger players." Kilmarnock kicks off their league season at home against St Johnstone on August 5. Stay updated on all football transfers on our dedicated page.

England are dealing with injuries in their back row as James Haskell, Sam Jones, and Mike Williams have all been sidelined, along with the adaptable Maro Itoje. Harrison, 24, managed just 30 minutes in England's last Test against Australia in Sydney. "He's returned and put in significant effort to improve," Jones told BBC Sport. "His recent performance against Castres was outstanding, making him likely our top pick for open-side flanker currently." Meanwhile, Jones notes that the returning flanker Tom Wood has a "strong chance" of being chosen this autumn. Wood was previously dropped after the Rugby World Cup, with Jones critiquing his past performances as "distinctly average." "He has enhanced his work-rate and impact as a ball carrier, and is now certainly above average," Jones added. "His lineout abilities are excellent and his breakdown skills have improved, making us excited to have him in the squad. His lineout prowess gives him a strong chance of selection." Jones has included six uncapped players in his 33-man squad but has minimized their chances of playing against the Springboks on 12 November. "Debuting against South Africa might not be ideal," Jones stated. England will head to Portugal for a training camp on Sunday, aiming to avoid injuries like those from the previous session in Brighton where three players were seriously hurt. "We are committed to ensuring an injury-free camp," Jones said. "However, we must prepare for international rugby, so we will be training with intensity."

Adopting the names of organizations like NASA and the Environmental Protection Agency, these rogue accounts are directly criticizing the president. Mr. Trump has dismissed climate change as a hoax. The @RogueNASA account describes itself as the "unofficial 'Resistance' team of NASA," emphasizing it is not an official NASA account and not run by government employees. "Come for the facts, stay for the snark," states the account. BBC News reached out to the rogue EPA account, @ActualEPAFacts, which explained their mission to ensure "factual information about climate change and other scientific research continues to be shared during the Trump administration." They identified themselves as three EPA employees who acted following a gag order that prevented them from discussing their research. Reports indicate the Trump administration aimed to restrict communication from certain government agencies, including the EPA. The official EPA Twitter hasn't posted since January 19, a day before Trump’s inauguration. @ActualEPAFacts expressed surprise at their following, now over 90,000, but also felt vulnerable. Other rogue accounts also boast large followings; @RogueNASA has over 370,000 followers after just a few tweets, and the rogue National Park Service account @AltNatParkSer has attracted over a million followers. Similar rogue accounts exist for the US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, describing themselves as "resistance" while mixing scientific facts with criticism of Mr. Trump. Some individuals behind these accounts claim to be dissatisfied government workers. @AltNatParkSer tweeted that it was managed by active NPS rangers and friends but later announced a leadership change to activists and journalists who were former scientists. The official Badlands National Park account had tweeted about global warming on Tuesday, but those tweets were removed. The creators of @AltNatParkSer said this motivated them to launch their account, and the existence of other alternative accounts appears to have followed the removal of the Badlands tweets, with some official US national park accounts tweeting about climate change the next day. By Nathan Williams, BBC UGC & Social news team.

According to a report by British Marine, representing the leisure, superyacht, and small commercial marine sectors, superyacht revenues reached £605 million for the year ending April 2016. Overall sector revenues increased by 1.6% to £3.01 billion, surpassing the £3 billion threshold for the first time since 2008-2009. However, the report forecasted a slowdown in growth for 2017 due to uncertainties surrounding Brexit negotiations, which might dampen demand. Total revenue had fallen following the financial crisis, hitting a low of £2.85 billion in the 2011-2012 fiscal year but has been gradually recovering since. The rise in revenues is attributed to increased engine and equipment manufacturing and higher sales of hire and charter boats. Exports dropped by 0.7% to £882 million, but British Marine noted that the pound's decline against the dollar and euro post-referendum had enhanced purchasing power for international customers. Nonetheless, marine businesses surveyed anticipated that this currency advantage would be short-lived. Howard Pridding, British Marine's chief executive, stated, "The industry remains robust - revenue is growing and we are taking on more employees. Despite post-referendum volatility affecting business and consumer confidence, the industry remains optimistic." The report indicated that industry growth might decelerate in 2017 due to increased economic instability as the UK approaches and navigates Brexit negotiations. Sunseeker and Princess are the UK's leading superyacht companies. Internationally, the industry ranks as the fourth largest by turnover.

On Thursday, Russia revealed a plan to create four "de-escalation zones" in Syria, with support from Turkey and Iran. However, the main Syrian opposition group is skeptical of the agreement. Meanwhile, government airstrikes reportedly hit central Hama province, and other areas faced shelling and gunfire. The opposition High Negotiations Committee (HNC) criticized the plan on Friday, citing a lack of "safeguards and compliance mechanisms," and rejected Iran as a guarantor. UN special envoy for Syria, Staffan de Mistura, told the BBC the deal is significant because three countries capable of enforcing it are involved. On Saturday, the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported that Syrian jets bombed rebel sites in Hama, confirmed by a rebel commander who noted fighting occurred after midnight, according to Reuters. The Syrian military has not commented. The Russian military announced the "memorandum on the creation of de-escalation areas" following discussions in Kazakhstan's capital, Astana. Russia's foreign ministry released the agreement's full text on Saturday, aiming to cease attacks from all sides, enable the safe and voluntary return of refugees, and ensure quick delivery of relief and medical aid. The zones will last six months, with borders to be finalized by Russia, Iran, and Turkey by June 4. Russian Deputy Defence Minister Alexander Fomin stated on Friday that Russian air forces hadn't bombed the zones since May 1, but would continue targeting IS militants elsewhere. The US has voiced concerns about Iran, claiming it "only contributed to the violence, not stopped it." While President Bashar al-Assad's Syrian government didn't sign the agreement, state news supports the plan. The Astana talks aimed to strengthen a frequently breached ceasefire originally agreed upon in December. Despite a partial ceasefire at the end of last year, violence persists across multiple fronts. Syria's conflict has resulted in over 300,000 deaths since its onset in 2011.

The legislation had already been approved by the country's Chamber of Deputies. The Senate's vote, narrowly passing the bill by six votes, followed a 14-hour session marked by intense debate. The law, which also permits same-sex couples to adopt, encountered strong resistance from the Catholic Church and various religious groups. President Cristina Fernandez's centre-left administration supported the bill, which passed with a vote of 33 to 27 and three abstentions. As the discussion stretched into the early hours of Thursday, supporters and opponents of the bill staged competing demonstrations outside Congress. "Nearly every political and social figure has expressed support for marriage equality," stated Maria Rachid, head of the Argentine Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals, and Transsexuals. "We hope the Senate reflects this, making Argentina a fairer nation for all families," she told the Associated Press. Ines Frank, from Argentine Families Argentina, argued that the opposition did not constitute discrimination, emphasizing that "the essence of a family is between two people of opposite sexes." Recent same-sex marriages in Argentina, some annulled by the Supreme Court, have sparked legal debates. While civil unions between same-sex partners are legal in Buenos Aires and some provinces, there was no national law governing them. Buenos Aires is recognized as one of the most gay-friendly cities in Latin America, being the first in the region to legalize same-sex unions. Same-sex civil unions are also permitted in Uruguay and parts of Brazil and Mexico, with gay marriage legal in Mexico City. To share your opinions, please join our discussion.

The party plans to endorse its 54 current MPs as candidates, with decisions pending on Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, who were originally elected as SNP MPs but now serve as independents. Meanwhile, Labour's executive is expected to finalize its candidate selections, and challengers have already emerged for the Conservatives and Lib Dems. The UK will vote on 8 June following Prime Minister Theresa May's announcement of a snap election, which was approved by MPs by a vote of 552 to 13. McGarry and Thomson were the only Scottish MPs who opposed the election, while SNP members abstained. If McGarry and Thomson do not return, the SNP will need five candidates, including three for seats not won in 2015. Several party activists have expressed interest in running for the SNP in the Glasgow East and Edinburgh West seats previously held by the two women. On Friday, the UK Labour party invited potential parliamentary candidates to apply via Twitter, with a deadline set for noon on Sunday. The Scottish party's executive group is convening over the weekend to finalize their selection process, with leader Kezia Dugdale stating they are prepared for the election. Ian Murray, the party's only MP in Scotland, launched his campaign for re-election in Edinburgh South on Friday, followed by Scottish Secretary David Mundell in Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale, and Tweeddale. Candidates from other parties have also begun to declare their intentions. Tory MSP Douglas Ross, elected to Holyrood in 2016, announced he will challenge SNP deputy leader Angus Robertson in Moray. Former Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson aims to contest John Nicolson in East Dunbartonshire, two years after he took the seat from her. The Lib Dems are using all-female shortlists in several target areas, including Edinburgh West, with decisions possibly made over the weekend.

The charity aims for 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by the civil war to be resettled by the year's end. As UN talks in Geneva approach, it noted that just 1.4% of Syrians have been assisted so far. Oxfam criticized the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 as insufficient, though Britain is also emphasizing aid to the region. With a pledge of £2.3 billion, the UK is the world's second-largest donor, after the US, for the humanitarian crisis in Syria. While acknowledging Britain's financial generosity, Oxfam insists it "can and should do more", asserting that countries with robust economies should bear more responsibility for refugees than nations like Lebanon and Jordan, where many Syrians currently reside. The charity urged the Geneva conference to produce "urgent solutions" and create "safe and legal routes" for refugees to receive a welcome in other countries. Oxfam evaluated the commitments of 28 OECD nations, which are signatories of the 1951 Refugee Convention, revealing promises to accept nearly 130,000 Syrian refugees, though only 67,000 have arrived. The 10% resettlement target by the end of 2016 aligns with the UN's identification of the most vulnerable Syrians needing resettlement. Oxfam's analysis shows Canada, Germany, and Norway have exceeded their "fair share" based on economic size. Meanwhile, Australia, Finland, Iceland, Sweden, and New Zealand have pledged over half of their fair share. In contrast, the UK plans to accept 22% of its fair share, the US merely 7%, and France just 4%. Mark Goldring, Oxfam GB's chief executive, stated: "It's shocking that while people continue to flee Syria, most countries have failed to provide a safe home for the most vulnerable."

The final print edition of Newsweek will be on December 31, marking the shift of newspapers and magazines to digital platforms as traditional advertising wanes. Newsweek combined forces with the online news site the Daily Beast two years ago. Tina Brown, the founder of the Daily Beast, stated that the site now attracts over 15 million unique visitors monthly, a 70% increase from the previous year. She expressed: "Leaving print is a challenging moment for all of us who cherish the charm of print and the unique weekly rush before Friday night's deadline." Originally launched in 1933, Newsweek was a weekly magazine that covered global happenings. However, like the ever-evolving world it reported on, the publishing industry has seen significant changes, especially in how people access news. Newsweek's subscriber base has dwindled from over 3 million at its peak to 1.5 million today. Combined with decreasing advertising revenue in traditional print media, this has compelled Newsweek to cease its print edition entirely. Newsweek Global, its digital-only version, will be subscription-based. This approach targets the 70 million users of tablet computers in the U.S., a number that has rapidly increased from just 13 million two years ago. Yet, despite the large potential market, increased competition poses challenges in distinguishing oneself digitally. "Approaching Newsweek's 80th anniversary next year, we must uphold the journalism that defines the magazine's mission and embrace a wholly digital future. This decision is not a reflection of the brand or journalism quality, which remains strong, but rather the tough economics of print publishing and distribution." Once the second-largest U.S. news weekly after Time, Newsweek faced declining circulation and lost advertising, leading to its sale by the Washington Post Company to Sidney Harman in August 2010, and subsequent merger with the Daily Beast three months later. Tina Brown, who became Lady Evans after her husband, renowned journalist Harold Evans, was knighted, is a former editor at Vanity Fair and The New Yorker. In 2008, she partnered with Barry Diller to launch The Daily Beast, a name drawn from the fictional newspaper in Evelyn Waugh's 1938 novel "Scoop."

Spencer Flower argued that his connection to a social housing firm was irrelevant in a 2013 debate about housing plans in east Dorset. However, he was found guilty of illegal voting, as the firm might have gained from the plan's approval. Despite this, the 72-year-old Conservative councillor can retain his public office. Flower, from Verwood, Dorset, received a six-month conditional discharge and was ordered to pay £930 in costs. A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court determined he violated the Localism Act 2011. Outside court, Flower declined to discuss his political future, expressing surprise and disappointment at the ruling, which he described as a decision based on a technicality. He noted the court issued the lightest penalty possible and highlighted the absence of personal gain or intent. Flower, also an East Dorset councillor, had voted in February 2013 on the area's core strategy while serving as a non-executive director for Synergy Housing Ltd, earning an annual allowance of about £5,000. Before the meeting, he declared his interest, but was still found guilty of voting "without reasonable excuse" due to his financial interest. The strategy involved Wimborne redevelopment plans, which could have enhanced some of Synergy's social housing through developers Wyatt. Flower was charged in November, stepping down as Dorset County Council leader to address the accusations. Previously, two charges of failing to disclose an interest in Zebra Property Solutions Ltd to local councils had been dropped. A Christchurch Borough Council and East Dorset District Council spokesperson stated Flower remains a council member, with local election nominations still open, leaving uncertainty about his candidacy.

Blackstar, the final album from the Starman, held the number one position for the third week, with Best of Bowie, Hunky Dory, and Ziggy Stardust also in the Top 10. Adele maintained the second spot, while Suede, influenced by Bowie, achieved the highest new entry at number six. Rihanna's latest album, Anti, didn't appear on the charts after its Thursday release. It was deemed ineligible because it was initially distributed for free on Tidal, since free downloads don't count towards the top 40 according to official chart rules. Despite this, Rihanna entered the singles chart with Work, her collaboration with Drake, debuting at 13 after just two days of sales. The top new entry at number three is a dance rendition of Tracy Chapman's Fast Car by London producer Jonas Blue. His tropical version, featuring Dakota's vocals, surpassed the original's success, which reached number five in 1988 and climbed to number four in 2011 after a Britain's Got Talent cover. Jonas Blue noted on Facebook that he wanted to recreate a favorite song from his mother's collection, which he often heard growing up. Canadian artist Shawn Mendes remains at number one with Stitches, outselling Justin Bieber's Love Yourself by 13,000 copies and becoming the week's most streamed song with 3.51 million plays. Meanwhile, Elle King's appearance on Graham Norton boosted her single Ex's & Oh's from 64 to 15, and her album Love Stuff rose 40 positions to number 18. Other Bowie albums in the top 40 include: Nothing Has Changed (5), Heroes (28), Diamond Dogs (30), Station to Station (32), and Scary Monsters (36).

On Sunday, Mr. Joshua informed his congregation that he had "seen" a woman winning. However, after Donald Trump won the election decisively on Tuesday, users noticed the prediction had been removed from his Facebook page. Known as "the prophet" among his followers, the affluent pastor is one of Nigeria's most prominent and influential evangelists, with a significant following across Africa that includes top politicians. His US election prediction aired on his TV channel, Emmanuel TV, and was uploaded to YouTube by someone. Part of the "prophecy" had been posted on his Facebook page, but it has since disappeared. It stated, "Ten days ago I saw the president of America with a narrow win... What I frankly saw was a woman." The prediction sparked trends on Twitter in Nigeria, Ghana, and South Africa, with memes ridiculing it. People also expressed their displeasure on a Facebook post he made on Wednesday. Clive Mashiri from South Africa questioned, "Why was the prophecy deleted? If it was spoken by the man of God, why remove it?" Despite the criticism, some defended him, with South African Gugu Mathonsi saying, "I will always believe in your prophecies, through thick and thin." Many believe TB Joshua possesses supernatural abilities, including healing and prophecy. Ghana's late President John Atta Mills mentioned in a speech at TB Joshua's thanksgiving service following his 2008 election win that he had sought the preacher's counsel during his campaign. Tanzanian President John Magufuli and former Malawian leader Joyce Banda have also acknowledged him in the past. Profile: Nigerian preacher TB Joshua. In pictures: TB Joshua's ministry in 2005.

Participants in the yearly competition have five minutes to tell the most elaborate and believable lie they can. This year's winner, George Kemp from Maryport, Cumbria, was shocked to claim victory as he was "struggling" with a chest infection. In his tale, he described "bumping into Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel." His story revolved around constructing a small submarine from his dad's old bubble car, which they took on a journey to the Isle of Man, where they encountered several celebrities in a Scottish submarine made from shortbread tins. "Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond sold some of these giant shortbread tin submarines to the United States," he added. Last year's winner, Mike Naylor, also known as Monkey Liar from Wasdale, took second place, while Helen Jordan secured third. Past victors include comedian and TV host Sue Perkins in 2006. In 2014, a participant even traveled from Germany to join the fun. The event takes place before a panel of judges and an audience at the Bridge Inn at Santon Bridge. Politicians and those in the legal field are barred from entering, as the rules consider them "too skilled to compete." The competition dates back to the 19th century, honoring the legendary storyteller Will Ritson, a Wasdale landlord. He famously claimed that the local turnips were so massive that people had to "quarry" into them for Sunday lunch, and they could then serve as sheds for Herdwick sheep from the fells.

Mark Footitt claimed 3-52 as the visitors lost five wickets before lunch, with Sam Curran taking out England's opener, Haseeb Hameed, for a second-ball duck. However, Clark's unbeaten 108 from 133 deliveries and Shivnarine Chanderpaul's solid 85 not out helped reconstruct the innings. Clark reached his century with a massive pulled six just before the close. The retired West Indies player, Chanderpaul, added 55 with Ryan McLaren, stabilizing the innings after the early wickets, before joining forces with Clark when Gareth Batty dismissed McLaren. Together, they forged an unbroken stand of 172, with Clark, batting at number eight, rapidly surpassing Chanderpaul's score, and reaching his half-century first. The game was paused due to poor light in the evening, but this did not hinder Clark's momentum. The 26-year-old, whose previous highest score was 84 not out, hit 17 fours and three sixes throughout his innings. Lancashire's turnaround was particularly notable given they were five down within 22 overs. Footitt, who took eight wickets in Surrey's season opener win against Warwickshire, dismissed opener Alex Davies, Lancashire's temporary captain Liam Livingstone, and Dane Vilas, while Sam and Tom Curran each took a wicket in the early collapse. Lancashire all-rounder Jordan Clark told BBC Radio Lancashire: "It's an incredible feeling for me. It puts us in a position to dig in more tomorrow and hopefully set the team up well. It was tough early on against the new ball, but the pitch eased up a bit when I came in. Tomorrow, the new ball is looming, so there's still a lot of work to do."

In the year leading up to August, the company's sales increased to €34.2 billion (£28.8 billion). The chain's opening of 12 new stores contributed to a 7.1% rise in total sales, although this was less than the previous year's 11% growth. Sales at stores open for over a year grew by 5%, matching last year’s figures. The privately-held Swedish company reported a roughly 20% surge in sales in Poland, marking it as its fastest-growing market, while Australia and Canada also showed strong performance. Germany remained the retailer's largest market, followed closely by the United States. This year, Ikea plans to launch its first stores in India and Serbia, bringing its total to 340 locations across 28 countries. However, its expansion in Russia is on hold due to "a number of old legal disputes." In the UK, Ikea has 19 stores and plans to open more in Exeter, Sheffield, and southeast London. Besides opening 12 new stores this year, Ikea also launched 19 "click and collect" outlets worldwide, adapting to changing consumer habits. The company has recently started offering online sales for home delivery or pickup, diverging from its traditional model where customers collect flat-pack items themselves. Online sales are capturing a larger portion of the UK furniture and floorcoverings market, rising 15% last year to over 12% of total spending, according to Verdict Retail. Earlier this year, Ikea CEO Peter Agnefjall projected annual sales could reach €50 billion by 2020. Ikea now releases its sales figures in September and profits in December. Additionally, it opened a museum in Almhult, Sweden, earlier this year, celebrating its founder Ingvar Kamprad's first store from 1958, showcasing iconic designs and products, including meatballs and bookshelves.

In March 1981, Mr. Reagan and three others were injured in a shooting outside a Washington hotel. The shooter, Mr. Hinckley, was found not guilty due to insanity and was committed to a Washington hospital for treatment. In July, a judge decided that Mr. Hinckley, now 61, posed no threat to himself or the public. Under strict conditions, he had been spending 17 days each month at his mother's home in Virginia. According to the Associated Press, he arrived at her home after being released on Saturday. This release coincides with the 30th anniversary of Reagan's shooting, an incident that shocked the world just weeks into his presidency. Mr. Reagan was shot in the lung but recovered, while his press secretary, James Brady, was shot in the head, resulting in brain damage that confined him to a wheelchair for life. Brady's death in 2014 at 73 was ruled a homicide, but no new charges were filed against Hinckley. Two law enforcement officers were also injured, though less seriously. US District Judge Paul Friedman's decision referenced medical evaluations indicating that Mr. Hinckley had shown "no symptoms of active mental illness" since 1983. He had shot President Reagan in a misguided attempt to impress actress Jodie Foster, whom he was obsessively infatuated with and had stalked. Details of Mr. Hinckley's release conditions, psychiatric history, and treatment are outlined in a court order available on the US District Court for the District of Columbia's website.

Emcol 2008 Ltd, the company operating the Haverfordwest abattoir, went under in January 2016, burdened with £660,000 in debts to more than 230 creditors. A director attributed this to rising costs and outstanding payments. Newport dairy farmer John Sollis described the situation as a "disaster" for local creditors. According to documents on the Companies House website, a livestock trader is owed over £107,000, with others facing significant five-figure losses. Liquidator Gary Stones reported that any potential payments to unsecured creditors hinged entirely on recovering debts from an Irish company, which owes Emcol nearly £470,000. Mr. Sollis, who is owed nearly £15,000, expressed concerns about the financial loss to the community and the inconvenience of lacking a local abattoir, forcing longer travel for livestock, which increases costs. The closest alternative is in Cross Hands, Carmarthenshire. NFU Cymru President Stephen James, owed just over £1,000, called the closure a "huge blow," noting that injured cows now have to be euthanized on farms, leading to further losses for farmers. Helen Lewis, a director at Emcol, cited the significant debt owed by an Irish company and rising abattoir operating costs as the reasons for the collapse. She expressed sympathy for the affected farmers, many of whom she knew personally.

Ben Purdy, 18, was fatally shot in the head in Bermondsey after confronting his girlfriend's ex over "threatening" messages sent post-breakup. Andrew Bayne, 37, from Trundleys Terrace, and his nephew Michael Bagnall, 22, from Hospital Way—both located in Lewisham—were convicted of the murder. They are due to be sentenced at the Old Bailey on 20 November. The court was told that Mr. Purdy, along with his friends Callum Malone and Jack Walker, approached Bagnall. Following the "skirmish" last November, the defendants drove around Bermondsey searching for Mr. Purdy. They found him in Mossington Gardens, where Andrew Bayne shot him in the head and then aimed the gun at Callum before fleeing. Mr. Purdy sustained "catastrophic injuries" and died the following day, the court heard. Although Bagnall had a new girlfriend, prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC explained that the breakup still "rankled" him, prompting him to send "threatening messages" via phone and Facebook. Mr. Aylett stated, "Ben evidently had enough and decided, with his two friends Callum and Jack, to confront Michael Bagnall and settle the matter. It was undoubtedly a very foolish action and it cost Ben Purdy his life." Bayne was also found guilty of possessing a firearm with intent, and Bagnall of affray. Upon hearing the guilty verdicts, Michael Bagnall began shouting and swearing in the dock and had to be escorted out by officers.

Masai Graham took the top spot with his quip: "My dad suggested I register for a donor card, he's a man after my own heart." The best jokes of the festival were chosen by a panel of 10 judges and then presented to 2,000 people who voted for their favorite. Previous winners of this competition, organized by TV channel Dave, include Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, and Zoe Lyon. Graham, hailing from West Bromwich, secured his win after being shortlisted in both 2014 and 2015. He remarked, "It's an incredible honor to land Joke of the Fringe. Not bad for someone from West Brom!" Comedian Stuart Mitchell came second with his joke: "Why is it old people say 'there's no place like home', yet when you put them in one..." The judges reviewed an average of 60 comedy performances and more than 3,600 minutes of content before choosing their favorite jokes. To ensure an unbiased selection, the names of the comedians or their shows are not disclosed during the voting. Steve North, Dave's general manager, noted: "The Fringe is known for showcasing new and emerging comedy talent, and while there are familiar faces in our top 10 this year, there's also a significant amount of new talent, which is very exciting to see." Voters also picked the most "groan-worthy" jokes of the festival, featuring Adam Hess' line: "In France, J-Lo is called 'I have water'", and Darren Walsh's joke: "What do you call three members of Abba in a French slaughterhouse? Abba trois."

The Halle Orchestra plans to establish a school in Stoke-on-Trent by 2020, catering to both primary and secondary students. The orchestra will collaborate with an academy trust to launch the school. John Summers, the orchestra's chief executive, stated that the initiative aims to use music to "raise aspirations" in various academic fields. The proposed school, in partnership with the City Learning Trust, is part of the free schools programme, and its opening is contingent on approval from the Department for Education. The orchestra targets a September 2020 opening for students aged seven to 19, promising masterclasses from musicians, concert access, and artists in residence. Students are expected to dedicate 40% of their time to specialized music classes with the Halle Choir, Halle Youth Orchestra, and Halle for Youth. John Summers highlighted the orchestra's extensive expertise in high-level performance, instrumental coaching, and choral training, emphasizing their role in enhancing the curriculum through music to boost academic success and ambition. Similar partnerships have been successful, such as in Bremen, Germany, where the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen integrated into a local school, resulting in reduced truancy and improved academic performance.

Leading the processions were individuals impacted by the suicide bombings at Belgium's airport and metro station, which resulted in 32 fatalities. Described by a Belgian broadcaster as "calm and silent," the march was initially scheduled a week after the 22 March attacks but was postponed due to security concerns. Victims' relatives, paramedics, and airport workers affected by the events joined people from various religious backgrounds in Sunday's march. Participants carried flowers to honor those who lost their lives. The procession passed through the Molenbeek neighborhood, home to many alleged attackers in both the Brussels and Paris incidents, culminating at a makeshift memorial outside the city's stock exchange. Hassan Bousetta, one of the organizers, told AFP: "When our fellow citizens, defenseless civilians, are attacked in such a cowardly manner, all citizens must rise to show their disgust and solidarity." The turnout was less than half the expected 15,000. The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the Brussels attacks, as well as the Paris attacks on 13 November that killed 130 people. Belgian police have arrested dozens in recent weeks, but authorities and other European security agencies face scrutiny over alleged failures and missed chances to dismantle the terror cell responsible for both attacks.

The company announced that it received approval from Senegal's government to initiate an evaluation plan. Cairn, having made two discoveries in the region last year, estimated that the fields could hold over a billion barrels of oil. The evaluation will begin soon with a 3D seismic survey, followed by a multi-well exploration and appraisal program later this year. Cairn, based in Edinburgh, holds a 40% stake in three offshore blocks in Senegal (Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, Rufisque Offshore). Its partners include ConocoPhillips with a 35% stake and FAR Ltd with 15%, while Petrosen, the Senegal National Oil Company, maintains a 10% interest during the exploration phase. Cairn also reported in its recent half-yearly update that it had initiated international arbitration with the Indian government over a tax dispute. Indian authorities have blocked Cairn from accessing the value of its remaining 10% shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). In March, Cairn was issued a $1.6 billion tax bill, plus interest and penalties, for the 2006-07 tax year, when it was preparing to list Cairn India on the Mumbai stock exchange. Cairn disputes the bill and aims to recover losses from the declining value of its CIL stake, which has decreased from $1 billion in December 2013 to $526 million as of June 30 this year. This lower valuation led Cairn to record a $177.1 million impairment loss in the first half, with a post-tax loss of $230 million, up from $62 million the previous year. The company, focused on exploration, generates no revenue but had a cash balance of $725 million at the end of the first half. On Tuesday morning, Cairn's share price fell by about 5%.

Tear gas and live ammunition were used to disperse predominantly Shia Muslim protesters rallying against corruption and security lapses. A curfew was enforced in Baghdad, which has since been lifted. This marked the second instance that month where demonstrators breached the city's governmental district. Shia cleric Moqtada Sadr criticized the forceful measures and expressed support for the protestors' "peaceful [and] spontaneous uprising." Reports indicate at least 50 protesters were injured. The demonstrators blame the government for ignoring crucial reforms while tackling the Islamic State group (IS) and facing dwindling oil revenues. The Sunni extremist group, responsible for recent deadly attacks, holds territories in Iraq's west and north. Some protesters accessed the prime minister's office and parliament. Baghdad's Green Zone, which contains parliament and key government and foreign embassy buildings, was later reported as fully secured with protesters retreating. Moqtada Sadr and his militia, the Mehdi Army, gained notoriety post-2003 US-led invasion by opposing US forces, which Sadr consistently called to withdraw. In 2004, an arrest warrant for Sadr was issued related to a rival cleric's murder. His militia was accused of severe sectarian violence against Sunnis in 2006 and 2007, forcing Sadr to flee to Iran. He returned in 2011, advocating Iraqi unity and peace. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, in power since 2014, has pledged to combat corruption and reduce sectarian strife. He aims to implement significant reforms and form a technocratic government but faces opposition from lawmakers, reports the BBC's Jim Muir. Deep parliamentary divisions prevent quorum achievement, hindering meetings, our correspondent adds. The Iraqi government, structured on party and sectarian lines, is criticized for promoting incompetence and corruption, ranking 161st out of 168 in Transparency International's corruption perceptions index.

Muslim cleric Mehboob Akhtar from Stoke-on-Trent, along with nine others including his wife and daughter, was sentenced for deceiving mortgage lenders to accumulate nearly £1 million in property to "control and dominate" parts of the city. Akhtar received a 14-year prison sentence from Birmingham Crown Court. Following last month's trial, the 60-year-old from Farman Close, Fenton, was found guilty of 11 charges, including five counts of conspiracy to commit fraud and defrauding Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC) of £271,000. The court detailed how Akhtar, also known as Saint Pirwali Pandariman, orchestrated the scheme over a decade, from 2003 to 2014. Originally from Pakistan, he was a respected faith leader in Fenton and helped raise millions in donations for poverty relief through the Darbar Unique Centre. However, Judge Stephen Eyre stated that Akhtar "let down his followers," using his spiritual influence to facilitate the crimes and funding his activities with donations partly obtained because of his religious role. The court learned that Akhtar avoided putting his name on most documents, using his wife, daughter, and niece to secure mortgages. A police raid in September 2012 on properties linked to the group revealed forged documents and emails related to the conspiracy. His wife, Khadija Akhtar, 54, from Hartwell Lane, Stoke, was found guilty of cheating HMRC and conspiracy to obtain money by deception, receiving a four-year, three-month sentence. Akhtar's daughter, Rushbamani Akhtar, 29, received a three-and-a-half-year sentence for facilitating the handling of criminal property and conspiracy to commit fraud. Seven others, including two mortgage brokers, were sentenced for conspiracy to defraud and obtaining money by deception. Chief Superintendent Martin Evans of Staffordshire Police highlighted the sentences as the outcome of a "very long and complex investigation."

The 23-year-old, raised in north Wales, credits her success to early inspirations like watching Kelly Holmes on TV. "Seeing people like her motivated me to aim for a gold medal," she said. "It's wonderful to think I'm now a role model with others looking up to me. Since London, I've noticed many more girls take up taekwondo after watching it on TV." Encouraged by her grandfather Martin to "stay off the streets," Jones began taekwondo at 15. "When I started, there were only four or five girls in the whole club," she noted. "Now there's so many more, and it's fantastic. Sports aren't just for boys—girls excel too." Ranked world number one in the -57kg category, Jones has won a World Grand Prix and two European titles since her London 2012 triumph. She became Britain's first Olympic taekwondo champion by defeating China's double world champion Yuzhuo Hou. Jones was the country's youngest Olympic champion, only two years after winning at the 2010 Youth Olympics in Singapore. Despite fluctuating motivation over the past four years, Jones is determined to capture another gold. "Before London, I joined the national team in 2010, just two years before the Olympics, and nobody expected me to even qualify," she told BBC Wales Sport. "I seized the moment and it paid off. This time, I've trained for four years with my focus on the Olympics. For me, the pinnacle has always been the Olympics."
