Remus Hamza, 40, is accused of assaulting the 20-year-old woman near Cardiff University as she walked home alone after a night out with friends on September 20. At Newport Crown Court, the prosecution claimed she was too intoxicated to consent to sex. Hamza, a Romanian resident of Cardiff, denies the rape charge. The court heard that the woman lost contact with her friends and began walking home via Greyfriars Road, passed under City Hall, and continued on Museum Avenue around 02:00 GMT. Here, the defendant allegedly approached her, and the rape reportedly took place behind a bush. Prosecutor Claire Pickthall informed the jury that the victim was "so drunk she can't remember the incident. She can't even recall him having sex with her." Her level of intoxication, she argued, meant she was incapable of consenting. "These actions under such circumstances constitute rape," Ms. Pickthall stated. "He was targeting solitary, intoxicated women." The court was told that Lee Neill, who saw Hamza walking with the victim near the National Museum of Wales, was concerned enough to follow them. Suspecting something "sinister," Neill took a photo "as evidence," which startled Hamza, causing him to flee. Neill pursued but lost him and returned to the victim, then called the police. However, when officers spoke to the victim, she was so disoriented that she mistakenly identified Neill as her attacker. He was arrested but later released. DNA evidence eventually led to Hamza's arrest. The woman testified that she drank wine, cider, and cocktails during the evening and could not recall much of her journey or the attack, but emphasized she would never consent to sex with a stranger. "I have a moral compass," she added.

In July 2016, 51-year-old Helen Bailey was discovered dead in a cesspit at her Royston, Hertfordshire home, after last being seen on April 11. Her fiancé, Ian Stewart, has pleaded not guilty to her murder. Initially, Edward Farmer told St Albans Crown Court that he saw her in a car in Broadstairs, Kent, sometime between mid-April and June, but later conceded it might have been weeks earlier. The jury learned that he claimed to have spotted Ms. Bailey on Charlotte Street, near her holiday home, driving a dark 4x4 vehicle resembling a Range Rover, alone. This contradicted defense claims that she had been kidnapped by two violent men and taken to Broadstairs. When asked about the timing of his sighting, Mr. Farmer estimated it was "about five, maybe six weeks prior to the police interview [on 13 July]." Mr. Stewart reported Ms. Bailey missing on April 15. During prosecution questioning, Mr. Farmer admitted the sighting could have occurred in March, weeks before she was reported missing. He also confessed he had "no reason at all" to consider the sighting until interviewed by a reporter from The Sun in June. Mr. Stewart, 56, from Baldock Road, Royston, Hertfordshire, faces charges of drugging Ms. Bailey before suffocating her and disposing of her body in the pit beneath their garage. He denies the charges of murder, preventing lawful burial, fraud, and three counts of perverting the course of justice. The trial is ongoing.

The Republican attempted to dismiss the remark with laughter, following a supporter’s statement: "We have a problem in this country - it's called Muslims." These comments were made during a campaign rally for Mr. Trump in New Hampshire. Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton criticized his lack of response to "hateful rhetoric," calling it "disturbing and wrong." Referring to the first questioner at the Rochester event, the billionaire businessman remarked, "I like this guy." The man continued, "We have a problem in this country called Muslims," claiming, "Our current president is one. You know he's not even an American." Mr. Trump, laughing, asked, "We need this question?" The man persisted, "We have training camps growing where they want to kill us. That's my question: When can we get rid of them?" Mr. Trump did not clarify that Mr. Obama is a Christian American; instead, he commented that "bad things are happening" and promised to investigate. Mrs. Clinton criticized Mr. Trump on social media, tweeting: "Donald Trump not denouncing false statements about POTUS & hateful rhetoric about Muslims is disturbing & just plain wrong. Cut it out." Democratic National Committee chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz stated that Mr. Trump's "racism knows no bounds." Mr. Trump's campaign manager Corey Lewandowski downplayed the incident, telling US media that he only heard a question about training camps. "The media wants to make this about Obama. The bigger issue is that Obama is waging a war against Christians in this country," Lewandowski told the Washington Post. This incident was reminiscent of a 2008 campaign moment when Republican nominee John McCain took the microphone from a woman who said she didn’t trust Mr. Obama because he was "an Arab." President Obama, who has openly discussed his Christian faith, was born in Hawaii to an American mother and a Kenyan father. However, Mr. Trump had been a prominent sceptic, challenging Mr. Obama in 2011 to release his birth certificate to disprove rumors of a Kenyan birth, which the president did. Despite having no political experience, Mr. Trump led his Republican rivals in the polls, with more than a year to go until election day. Meet all of the 2016 hopefuls.

He's acclimating to media interactions and outlining his policies, which differ significantly from those of his predecessor. Mr. Corbyn has expressed strong disapproval of the government's handling of the Calais migrant crisis, urging the UK to take more action. He stated, "These are human beings in dire circumstances who need our assistance and support." He pointed out the substantial efforts by people traveling to Calais to provide aid and emphasized that the UK should participate in the European program for Syrian and other refugees. His stance on immigration starkly contrasts with the UK Independence Party, whose leader Nigel Farage discussed the issue at their annual conference in Doncaster today. Farage questioned how a government could plan effectively for schools and healthcare without knowing the population size within a couple of years to the nearest million. Similarly, Kent Conservative MP and former immigration minister Damian Green described open-door immigration as irresponsible. Nonetheless, Mr. Corbyn maintains that immigration benefits the UK, noting the contributions immigrants have made to the health service, education, and industrial development, creating a vibrant cosmopolitan society. He believes immigration should be embraced for the opportunities it presents. This is a message he plans to convey at the party meeting in Brighton this weekend. Additionally, he aims to address issues like the housing crisis, infrastructure investment, and his stance against benefits reform. He is determined to connect with not just the Labour members who supported him but also with voters in the South East who have drifted from the party in recent elections. Despite recognizing the challenges, Mr. Corbyn is optimistic about winning back support in the South East and is eager to tackle this challenge. The Labour conference will take place in Brighton from September 27 to 30.

In September 2014, the bodies of two backpackers, 23-year-old Miss Witheridge from Norfolk and 24-year-old Mr. Miller from Jersey, were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao. Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Tun, Burmese bar workers, were convicted of the murders in December 2015, and a Thai appeal court upheld their death sentences. The men's lawyers have 30 days to appeal to Thailand's Supreme Court, the final court of appeal. Last May, the mothers of the accused filed appeals in Koh Samui court, raising concerns about the judgments, particularly the DNA evidence used. Andy Hall, legal advisor to the families, stated, "We don't believe the court can say beyond reasonable doubt that Zaw Lin and Wai Phyo were responsible for the events which took place in September 2014." Miss Witheridge, a University of Essex student, and Mr. Miller, a civil and structural engineering graduate, were found bludgeoned to death on the beach. A post-mortem showed Miss Witheridge had been raped. Prosecutors claimed DNA evidence from cigarette butts, a condom, and the victims' bodies connected Lin and Phyo to the murders. The men, from Myanmar, later retracted their initial confessions, alleging police torture. Their lawyers argued that DNA from a garden hoe, supposedly the murder weapon, did not match their samples, and claimed evidence was mishandled and their confessions were coerced through "systematic abuse" of migrants in the area.

The sum in question matches the size of the combined economies of Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, Spain, and the United Kingdom, according to a report by the Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP). The annual report highlighted an increasing gap between the most and least peaceful countries. Iceland is deemed the most peaceful, while Syria is the least. Libya experienced the greatest decline in peace during 2014, noted the Australia-based IEP. The Middle East and North Africa have now surpassed South Asia as the world's most violent region, a title South Asia held in 2013. Conflicts claimed 180,000 lives in 2014, up from 49,000 in 2010. The report also said terrorism-related deaths rose by 61% in 2013, resulting in nearly 18,000 fatalities, primarily in Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Nigeria, and Syria. If global violence decreased by 10%, it would add Â£1.43 trillion to the economy, according to the IEP. IEP Chief Executive Steve Killelea noted the surprising "inequality with peace" worldwide. Some Western European countries have reached historically low murder rates and security spending. Conversely, violence has increased in Iraq, Syria, Nigeria, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic. The IEP reported that conflict-related costs equal 13.4% of global GDP. Rising expenses stem from internal conflict deaths, internally displaced persons (IDPs), refugee support, UN peacekeeping, and GDP losses due to conflict. The cost to support around 50 million refugees and IDPs, the largest figure since WWII, has surged 267% since 2008 to $128 billion. The report also highlighted that reducing global violence by 10% could boost the world economy by $1.43 trillion, which is over six times what is required to eliminate Greece's debts, and three times the total earnings of approximately 1.1 billion of the world's poorest people.

Falcon and Pointer faced a £175,000 fine for making automated PPI calls, while Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd was fined £50,000 for requesting to speak with deceased relatives of individuals. Both firms attributed the calls to a third party. Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, emphasized that this serves as a "clear message to callous cold-callers." She remarked that Swansea is increasingly being identified as the UK's hub for cold-calling. Businesses in the area have been exploiting aggressive business tactics rooted in illegal practices to place calls that range from annoying to upsetting. Since 2013, the commissioner (ICO) has taken measures against six companies. Falcon and Pointer had its license revoked in January 2016, claiming to have ceased calls in June 2015, yet an inquiry revealed they conducted an additional two million calls over the next two months. Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd, which offers windows, doors, and conservatories, faced 168 complaints over six months. Ms. Jones stated their actions send a clear warning to cold-callers in Swansea to adhere to the rules, having previously warned the companies, which defied the law and continued their intrusive calls, leaving many feeling aggravated and targeted. Sandra Busby, managing director of the Welsh Contact Centre Forum, noted that there will always be a place for reputable companies reaching out to existing customers, as consumers sometimes seek the best deals and offers. The market becomes problematic with unscrupulous firms ignoring regulations, tarnishing the industry's reputation. The Welsh Contact Centre Forum supports companies striving for excellence. The ICO's recent actions coincide with the release of its updated Direct Marketing Guidance, designed to help organizations comply with laws and adopt best practices.

The protest walkout is a response to the firing of two nurses, Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton, who were involved in a violent altercation with a patient. According to the Prison Officers' Association (POA), the nurses used "reasonable force" against the unidentified patient. However, the Mersey Care Trust, which oversees Ashworth, stated that the evidence left them with no choice but to terminate the nurses' employment. The situation at the facility, one of the three high-security hospitals in England and Wales, began at 07:00 GMT. Steve Gillan, the POA's general secretary, expressed that the public would likely be outraged and empathetic towards Mr. Hilton and Mr. Gregson, as they were reacting to a violent incident where the patient headbutted a colleague and spat at staff. He argued that the restraint used was reasonable, and while there should be a duty of care for patients, it should also extend to staff. The trust expressed "disappointment" at the union's decision to strike before the independent employment tribunal hearing. "We do not believe this is in the best interests of our patients, our carers, our staff, and the communities we serve," the trust stated. Regarding the nurses' situation, the trust highlighted its care for "some of the most complex and vulnerable adults in a hospital setting" and mentioned their international, award-winning reputation. "Our staff are highly trained... We never dismiss staff lightly," it added. Given the evidence, the trust felt compelled to dismiss the two staff members. The other high-security psychiatric hospitals in England and Wales are Rampton in Nottinghamshire and Broadmoor in Berkshire.

The oil painting Women Lovers by Charles Blackman, which depicts two nude women lying on a bed with a cat, faced rejection from Facebook when art broker Mossgreen attempted to advertise it. The social media platform dismissed the ad, citing a policy against "advertising adult products or services." Mossgreen's CEO, Paul Summer, criticized the move as "ridiculous," explaining to the BBC that the image is not explicitly sexual. He compared the decision to outdated censorship from the 1950s. Facebook insisted its decision was conclusive, although Mossgreen later managed to repost images of the artwork. Facebook justified its stance, stating such ads lead to negative user reactions and are not tolerated. In a related incident, a French teacher previously sued Facebook after it deactivated his account for sharing a 19th-century nude painting by Gustave Courbet. Summer mentioned that Women Lovers was anticipated to fetch over A$45,000 (£28,000; $34,000) at an upcoming auction. He questioned Facebook's reasoning, noting that his teenage daughters would find the ban absurd. Blackman, now 88, is considered a key figure from a notable period in Australian art, alongside contemporaries like Arthur Boyd, Sidney Nolan, and Albert Tucker. Last year, Blackman's The Game of Chess sold for A$1.78m at Sotheby's Australia. Summer described Blackman as "the most well-regarded and respected living Australian artist."

The Spy Who Came In From The Cold, set during the peak of the Cold War, is being adapted by Simon Beaufoy, the Oscar-winning writer of Slumdog Millionaire. The story centers on Alec Leamas, a British intelligence officer with a faltering network in East Berlin. Le Carre expressed his excitement about the series, which will air on BBC One. This project is another collaboration with the US network AMC, following their previous partnership on The Night Manager. Tom Hiddleston, Hugh Laurie, and Olivia Colman all received Golden Globes for their performances in that series, which was also nominated for best mini-series or TV film. The Spy Who Came In From The Cold takes place in 1962, shortly after the Berlin Wall was erected. The plot follows Leamas as his agents are either fleeing or dead due to the East German counter-intelligence officer Hans-Dieter Mundt. Leamas returns to London, where he gets the chance to seek revenge. Originally published in 1963, the novel was adapted into a 1965 film starring Richard Burton. Le Carre is eager to see it brought to screen once more, stating his confidence in the project. Beaufoy remarked on the thrill of adapting what he considers the greatest Cold War spy story. The series will be produced by The Ink Factory, known for The Night Manager, in partnership with Character 7. Piers Wenger, the controller of BBC Drama, commented: "After the global success of The Night Manager, we're honored to bring John le Carre back to BBC One with this outstanding spy thriller."

OUP examined over 120,421 short stories from children aged five to 13, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. The OUP found that while new technology is central to children's lives, the way they write about it is rapidly evolving. Terms like email, mobile, and Facebook are decreasing in use, being replaced by Instagram, Snapchat, and emoji. The term television is now being overtaken by phone. The report highlights the emergence of the hashtag symbol # in children's writing, used to add meaning or comments at the end of sentences, such as #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta from Oxford University Press noted: "This change in 2015 marked a significant shift with children using the hashtag beyond a simple prefix or Twitter search term to an editorial tool for emphasis or commentary." Words like iPod, mp3, and Blackberry are fading, replaced by iPhone, WhatsApp, and ooVoo. #keepup A frequent plotline in the competition involved characters gaining instant internet fame from posting YouTube videos, focusing on the number of hits, shares, and likes rather than just watching videos. #makesabetterstory Popular characters included Cinderella, Lionel Messi, Snow White, Adolf Hitler, and Wayne Rooney. Researchers were surprised by the frequent use of mythological figures such as Zeus, the Minotaur, and Hercules. #theyloveZeus World War One was a common story source, with current events in Ukraine and Syria also featured, though less than the most popular topic, Ebola, with many stories about finding a cure. New words introduced included wellysaurus, gloomful, and Stegasuarez, a hybrid of a Stegosaurus and footballer Luis Suarez. #itbites The winners will be announced on Friday on The Chris Evans Breakfast Show on BBC Radio 2, live from St James's Palace, with support from the Duchess of Cornwall.

The 23-year-old Heracles striker mentioned he was awaiting the completion of a transfer to the Championship club. However, Slade dismissed these reports, stating they were unfounded but acknowledged having shown interest in the player "some time ago." He clarified, "To my knowledge, that's not something we're going to pursue." Netherlands Under-21 player Weghorst, who started with FC Emmen before moving to Heracles in 2014, was said by Heracles chairman Jam Smit to have an agreed fee with Cardiff, despite rumors linking him to Celtic. Slade remarked, "It seems the speculation about the player originates from the Netherlands," noting there was an initial inquiry earlier. Slade aims to secure up to three new signings during the window to boost Bluebirds' Championship play-off aspirations, currently trailing the top six by four points. A striker is a priority following last season's top scorer Kenwyne Jones's move to Al Jazira in the UAE. Jones had claimed via social media that no renewal offer was made to him, but Slade refuted this, saying discussions were taking place among Jones, his representatives, and the club's board. Slade also refuted Rotherham Manager Neil Redfearn's claims about talks regarding Alex Revell's potential transfer. Revell, 32, joined Cardiff from Rotherham in January 2015, scoring twice in 15 league matches for the team. "We've already lost a target-type center forward," Slade commented. "We must ensure we have enough players in every position and area of the pitch." Cardiff will face League One's Shrewsbury Town on Sunday in the FA Cup third round, with defender Lee Peltier doubtful due to illness.

NHS England announced that the walk-in service is designed to lessen doctor appointments and curb the excessive use of antibiotics. The initiative aims to reduce GP visits, potentially saving the NHS millions annually. However, pharmacies warn that funding cuts might threaten the program. The Sore Throat Test and Treat service, trialed in 35 Boots pharmacies, identifies if an illness is viral, requiring no antibiotics, or bacterial. Throat swab results, assessing sugars on the tongue, are available in five minutes. Pharmacists can prescribe antibiotics without GP visits if necessary. NHS CEO Simon Stevens stated the scheme will expand nationwide over the next year. Dr. Adam Roberts, an antibiotic resistance expert at University College London, described it as an "innovative step," noting that only 36 out of 360 participants received prescriptions, a significant reduction. Claire Ward, chair of Pharmacy Voice, supported the rollout, emphasizing the role of community pharmacies, but cautioned that service cuts could hinder the scheme. In October, the Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee reported that the government proposed a 12% funding cut from December. The Department of Health has not finalized any decision. The throat test is one of eight innovations to help modernize the NHS amidst rising demand. Sir Bruce Keogh, NHS England's national medical director, emphasized that innovation is essential for a sustainable NHS, stating the selected innovations could provide better taxpayer value while enhancing patient interactions with the NHS.

Researchers at the University of Bristol report that the Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island is becoming an increasing threat. Situated 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant and near Kagoshima, a city with 600,000 residents, Sakurajima has not had a deadly eruption since 1914, which killed 58 people. Japan, part of the Pacific "Ring of Fire," hosts over 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima frequently emits ash and experiences numerous small explosions annually, the latest occurring in February. Japanese authorities closely monitor it, and it is one of two volcanoes at Level 3 in the nation's five-level volcanic warning system, advising people to stay away. Dr. James Hickey, the study's lead author now at the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines, says, "The 1914 eruption had a volume of about 1.5 km cubed. We estimate it would take around 130 years for the volcano to accumulate enough magma for a similar eruption, meaning we are roughly 25 years away." A report published on Tuesday involved teams from Bristol University and the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre. Their research discovered that 14 million cubic meters of magma accumulate annually, enough to fill London's Wembley Stadium 3.5 times. The accumulation rate surpasses the discharge through smaller eruptions, suggesting a significant eruption is probable within 30 years.
